questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, positive Romberg sign, and other neurological findings suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. Laboratory findings show elevated homocysteine levels. Which amino acid is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Methionine

Explanation:

  • The patient's anemia, positive Romberg sign, neurological symptoms, and elevated homocysteine indicate vitamin B12 deficiency, which impairs methionine synthase activity and leads to methionine deficiency despite high homocysteine levels.

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

  • Methyl-malonyl-CoA Mutase:
    • Function: Converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.
    • Methyl-malonyl CoA is an intermediate in the breakdown of valine, cholesterol, odd-chain fatty acids, propionate, and carboxylation of propionyl-CoA.
    • Deficiency Impact: Leads to accumulation of methylmalonyl-CoA and increased urinary methylmalonic acid, indicating B12 deficiency status.
    • Methylmalonic acid will be normal in megaloblastic anaemia caused by folate deficiency.
  • Methionine Synthase:
    • Function: Converts homocysteine to methionine.
    • Role: Impairment affects folic acid metabolism, leading to functional folate deficiency.
    • Deficiency Impact: Causes pernicious anaemia and spinal cord degeneration due to failed methylation of arginine in myelin basic protein. This is a result of methionine deficiency in the CNS.

 

Incorrect Options:

Cysteine (Option A): Synthesized from homocysteine via the transsulfuration pathway (requires vitamin B6), not directly affected in B12 deficiency.

Tyrosine (Option C): Formed from phenylalanine, unrelated to B12 metabolism.

Glutamate (Option D): Involved in nitrogen metabolism and neurotransmission; not affected by B12 or homocysteine levels.

questions.text: At how many months of intrauterine life does the talus begin to develop from a single primary ossification center?

questions.text: A laboring woman is found to have fetal bradycardia on fetal monitoring along with maternal tachycardia. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Artificial rupture of membranes

Explanation: The correct answer is artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) because in the setting of sudden fetal bradycardia, the first immediate bedside action is to perform a per vaginal (PV) assessment.

  • ARM allows visualization of the liquor for meconium (suggesting fetal distress) or blood staining (suggesting abruption) and to check for cord prolapse.
  • These findings guide the next step, if a reversible cause is not found and bradycardia persists, emergency cesarean section is performed without delay.

Emergency cesarean section (Option A): While often the definitive management in persistent fetal bradycardia, jumping straight to surgery without ruling out reversible intrapartum causes like cord prolapse may delay a potentially simpler and faster intervention.

Wait and watch (Option B): Inappropriate in acute fetal bradycardia, delaying action risks irreversible hypoxic injury.

Start oxytocin infusion (Option D): Contraindicated in fetal bradycardia, it can worsen hypoxia by increasing uterine contractions.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RUL collapse

Explanation: The image shows a tracheal shift towards the right side, which indicates volume loss in the right lung.

  • Right upper lobe (RUL) collapse causes ipsilateral mediastinal shift, elevation of the horizontal fissure, and crowding of ribs.
  • Collapse (atelectasis) results in a "pull" effect, drawing the trachea towards the affected side - unlike a mass or effusion, which usually pushes it away.

RUL consolidation (Option B): No significant volume loss, so trachea usually remains central or shifts away slightly if there is a large mass effect.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C): May cause collapse if obstructing bronchus, but the primary radiological sign here is collapse itself, not the mass.

Lung abscess (Option D): Produces a cavity with air-fluid level but does not typically cause significant tracheal shift toward the lesion unless there is secondary collapse.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the normal vascular composition of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2 arteries and 1 vein

Explanation:

  • The umbilical cord contains two arteries that carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta, and one vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta back to the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1 artery and 2 veins: This is incorrect because the umbilical cord normally has two arteries and only one vein, not the other way around.

Option B - 1 vein and 1 artery: This represents an abnormal or incomplete vascular arrangement, often linked to congenital anomalies.

Option D - 2 arteries and 2 veins: The umbilical cord typically contains only one vein, so having two veins is not normal.

questions.text: According to the population strategy for prevention of coronary artery disease, what is the recommended dietary cholesterol intake limit per day?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 100 mg / 1000 kcal:

Explanation:

  • The population-based dietary recommendations advocate limiting cholesterol intake to approximately 100 mg per 1000 kcal consumed to effectively reduce serum cholesterol levels and lower the risk of coronary artery disease.

  • This conservative limit helps in managing overall lipid profiles in the general population.

questions.text: Patient came with fever headache and nuchal rigidity. LP shows gram negative diplococci in gram stain. Which of the following will be used for chemoprophylaxis in close contacts of a patient with meningococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rifampicin

Rifampicin is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of patients with Neisseria meningitidis meningitis. It eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage and prevents secondary cases.

  • Alternatives for those intolerant to rifampicin include ciprofloxacin (adults) and ceftriaxone (pregnancy).

Amoxicillin (Option A): DOC for Listeria meningitis & used for certain bacterial infections, but ineffective for eradicating meningococcal carriage.

Doxycycline (Option B): Tetracycline antibiotic, not used for meningococcal chemoprophylaxis.

Ethambutol (Option C): Anti-tubercular drug, no role in meningococcal prophylaxis.

questions.text: A man is climbing a mountain for trekking. Based on his physiological response to the high altitude, what is the most likely primary acid-base abnormality in his blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

  • As a person ascends to high altitude, the atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen (PaO₂) decreases, triggering physiological responses such as respiratory alkalosis.

Changes during Acclimatization

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation.
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis. (Option D)
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count.
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular

  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content.
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Metabolic acidosis is not seen primarily; could occur later due to lactic acidosis, but not initially.

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis is unrelated to the primary high-altitude response.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis would occur with hypoventilation, not hyperventilation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with jaundice and splenomegaly. His father had a similar illness during adolescence. The MCHC was high. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hereditary spherocytosis

Explanation:

Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)
  • An inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red blood cell membrane skeleton, leading to spheroid, less deformable red cells vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
  • 75% of cases are autosomal dominant.
  • Remaining cases often involve severe forms due to compound heterozygosity (inheritance of two different defects).

Etiopathogenesis

  • HS is marked by a loss of membrane surface area relative to the intracellular volume, leading to spherical red blood cells with reduced or absent central pallor.
  • Spherocytes have decreased deformability, resulting in their retention and destruction in the spleen, causing hemolysis.
  • spectrin, ankyrin, AE1(band 3), protein 4.2 that weakens the vertical connections between the cytoskeletal framework and lipid bilayer.
  • The ANK1 gene on chromosome 8p produces Ankyrin.
  • Two proposed mechanisms for membrane loss:
    • In cells with spectrin/ankyrin deficiency.
    • Reduced AE1/protein.

Clinical features
  • 60-70% of patients present with moderate disease, typically in infancy or childhood.
  • Common findings in children include:
    • Anaemia may be asymptomatic,
    • Jaundice is usually intermittent and acholuric (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia).
    • >75% show palpable splenomegaly.
    • Family history.

Complications
  • Gallbladder Disease: Chronic hemolysis can lead to bilirubinate gallstones.
  • Crisis Events:
    • Hemolytic Crisis: Commonly associated with viral illnesses in childhood; typically mild and self-resolving.
    • Aplastic Crisis: Rare but may cause severe anaemia and require hospitalisation, often linked to parvovirus infection. Typically lasts 10–14 days and may reveal undiagnosed HS in asymptomatic patients.
    • Megaloblastic Crisis: Occurs in patients with increased folate needs, preventable by supplementation.
  • Other rare complications may include leg ulcers, chronic dermatitis, and skeletal abnormalities.
  • HS has been associated with increased risks of hematologic malignancies and thrombotic events post-splenectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): Usually microcytic, hypochromic anaemia with low MCHC, no jaundice, no splenomegaly, and no strong family history.

Thalassemia minor (Option C): Presents in infancy with severe anaemia, failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone deformities; MCHC is not elevated, and family history often shows transfusion-dependent anaemia.

AIHA (Option D): Can also have spherocytes and jaundice, but is typically acquired, not familial, and the Coombs test is positive. It is often acute/subacute onset, not a chronic familial condition.

questions.text: In a district-level survey, the introduction of breast cancer screening showed an increased 5-year survival rate, but autopsy data revealed no change in mortality. What type of bias does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lead time bias

Explanation:

  • Lead time bias occurs when earlier detection of disease (through screening) increases measured survival time without affecting the actual time of death, giving a false impression of benefit.

Incorrect Options:

Survival bias (Option A) relates to selection of survivors.

Berksonian bias (Option C) is related to hospital-based selection bias.

Detection bias (Option D) refers to differences in ascertainment or diagnosis rates between groups.

questions.text: During hyperextension, the long head of triceps gets detached from which site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Infraglenoid tubercle

Explanation:

  • During hyperextension injuries, particularly with forceful backward arm movements as seen in overhead sports or trauma, the long head of the triceps may be stretched or avulsed from its origin at the infraglenoid tubercle.

Triceps Brachii

Origin

  • Long Head: Infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula
  • Lateral Head: Posterior surface of the humerus, above the radial (spiral) groove
  • Medial Head: Posterior surface of the humerus, below the radial (spiral) groove.

Insertion

  • Olecranon process of the ulna (3 heads insert via a common tendon)

Nerve supply
  • Radial nerve (C6, C7, C8)
  • Medial head often receives branches directly in the axilla.

Function

  • Primary extensor of the forearm at the elbow joint
  • Shoulder extension and adduction

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Supraglenoid tubercle: Origin of the long head of the biceps brachii, not triceps.

Option C - Shaft of humerus: Gives origin to the lateral and medial heads of the triceps, not the long head.

Option D - Olecranon process: This is the insertion point of all three heads of the triceps, not the origin.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mass in the front of the neck, along with odynophagia and dyspnea. Histopathology reveals tumour cells positive for TTF-1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, and there is evidence of amyloid deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario with IHC positive for TTF-1, synaptophysin, and chromogranin and evidence of amyloid deposition is all suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma, which has amyloid deposition derived from calcitonin, known as A-CAL.

1. Clinical Features

Origin: Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid (neuroendocrine cells).
Hormone secreted: Calcitonin (does not cause hypocalcemia in most cases).
Presentations:

  • Neck mass: Firm, non-tender, may be solitary or multiple.
  • Local compressive symptoms:
    • Odynophagia (painful swallowing)
    • Dyspnea (tracheal compression)
    • Hoarseness (recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement)
  • Systemic symptoms
    • Diarrhea and flushing (due to hormone secretion like calcitonin, serotonin, VIP in some cases)
  • Family history:
    • MEN 2A or 2B syndromes (pheochromocytoma, parathyroid hyperplasia in 2A; mucosal neuromas and Marfanoid habitus in 2B).

2. Investigations

A. Laboratory tests

  • Serum calcitonin: Elevated (marker for diagnosis and follow-up).
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): Often elevated; used for prognosis.
  • RET proto-oncogene mutation testing: In patients and first-degree relatives.

B. Imaging

  • Neck ultrasound: Hypoechoic solid nodule, may show cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • CT/MRI: For extent and metastasis assessment.
  • Radioiodine scan: Usually negative (C cells do not take up iodine).

C. Histopathology

  • Tumour cells: Polygonal/spindle-shaped, arranged in nests/trabeculae.
  • Amyloid deposition in stroma (derived from calcitonin).
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • TTF-1 → confirms thyroid origin
    • Synaptophysin & chromogranin → confirm neuroendocrine nature
    • Calcitonin positive in tumour cells.

3. Diagnosis

Definitive diagnosis:

  • Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) cytology → suspicious for MTC.
  • Confirmed by immunohistochemistry for calcitonin and neuroendocrine markers + histologic amyloid.
  • Elevated serum calcitonin strongly supports the diagnosis.

questions.text: In a patient who presents with Phrynoderma as shown. What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ocular examination

Explanation:

Phrynoderma, as illustrated and commonly known as "toad skin," presents with follicular hyperkeratotic papules, and since it is strongly linked to vitamin A deficiency—which can lead to ocular complications—the appropriate next step is an ocular examination to check for signs like xerosis, Bitot’s spots, or other early eye involvement.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations

Ocular manifestations

Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.

  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia: Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
    • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
    • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

Immune Function
  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions
  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium. (Option A)
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

Other General Manifestation
  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

 

WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

Incorrect Options:

Check vitamin D levels (Option B): Vitamin D is not primarily associated with phrynoderma.

Check vitamin B12 levels (Option C): B12 deficiency presents with neurologic symptoms, not follicular keratosis.

Check for DTR (Option D): Deep tendon reflexes are not relevant to the cutaneous signs of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: CD markers can be detected by which of the following tests?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flow cytometry

Explanation:

CD markers (Cluster of Differentiation) are surface proteins used to identify and classify immune cells, and they are typically detected using Flow Cytometry, which employs fluorescent-labeled antibodies.

  • Principle: Detects physical and chemical characteristics of individual cells in a fluid stream using laser-based technology.
  • Detects:
    • CD markers (surface antigens) using fluorescent-labeled antibodies.
    • Cell size, granularity, and fluorescence.
  • Used in:
    • Immunophenotyping (e.g., leukemia/lymphoma classification)
    • Stem cell enumeration
    • Monitoring HIV (CD4 count)
  • Output: Dot plots or histograms showing expression of specific markers.

Incorrect Options:

Cytogenetics (Option A): Detects chromosomal abnormalities, not surface markers.

Next-generation sequencing (NGS) (Option B): Detects gene mutations, not surface proteins.

Karyotype (Option D): Analyzes chromosome structure and number, not proteins.

questions.text: A 20-year-old resident of Andhra Pradesh presents with outward bending of the lower limbs and signs of osteoporosis. His diet mainly consists of rice and jowar roti. What should not be done in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Provision of running surface water for drinking
Add lime and alum to drinking water

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fluoride supplementation:

Explanation:

  • The presentation — outward bending of limbs (genu valgum/varum), osteoporosis, and location in a fluorosis-endemic region — is consistent with skeletal fluorosis caused by chronic ingestion of high-fluoride water.
    • Fluoride supplementation in such cases is contraindicated because it would worsen bone and joint deformities by further increasing bone fluoride content.
    • Management focuses on reducing fluoride exposure, improving nutrition (especially calcium and vitamin D), and providing safe water.
  • Provision of running water (Option A), changing water source (Option B), and adding lime and alum (Option D) help reduce contaminants and improve water quality.

questions.text: A patient with tumour lysis syndrome has elevated uric acid levels. What is the mechanism of action of pegloticase?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oxidises uric acid

Explanation:

Pegloticase is a recombinant, pegylated form of uricase (urate oxidase).

  • Humans lack uricase naturally, so uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism.

  • Pegloticase catalyzes the oxidation of uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble and easily excreted compound.

  • This rapidly lowers serum uric acid levels, which is especially useful in tumor lysis syndrome and refractory chronic gout.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Xanthine oxidase inhibition: This is the mechanism of allopurinol and febuxostat, which block the enzyme xanthine oxidase, preventing conversion of hypoxanthine → xanthine → uric acid. Pegloticase does not inhibit production, it breaks down uric acid already present.

Option B - Urat-1 receptor inhibition: URAT1 is a transporter in the renal proximal tubule that reabsorbs uric acid from the urine back into the blood.

  • Lesinurad inhibits URAT1 to increase renal excretion of uric acid.

  • Pegloticase works enzymatically, not via transporter inhibition.

Option D - Excretion of uric acid: Uricosuric agents like probenecid act by increasing urinary excretion of uric acid. Pegloticase’s action is enzymatic conversion, not direct enhancement of excretion.

questions.text: An urban city has a population of 70,00,000, with 30% residing in slum areas. According to NUHM (National Urban Health Mission) norms, how many Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHCs) are required for the slum population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 42:

Explanation:

  • Under NUHM guidelines, one Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) is established for every 50,000 people living in slums.
    • Total population = 7,000,000
    • Slum population = 30% of 7,000,000 = 2,100,000
    • Required UPHCs = 2,100,000 ÷ 50,000 = 42
    • This ensures equitable access to primary healthcare services for underserved urban slum populations.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory investigations reveal a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA). Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Adenosine deaminase (ADA) is essential for purine metabolism.
    ADA deficiency → accumulation of deoxyadenosine → toxic to lymphocytes. This causes severe deficiency of both T cells and B cells, leading to SCID.

Clinical presentation:

  • Presents in infancy: recurrent bacterial, viral, fungal, and opportunistic infections.
  • Failure to thrive is common due to chronic infections and malnutrition.

Management:

  • Lymphopenia, low/absent immunoglobulins, absent thymic shadow on chest X-ray.
  • Treatment: hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; enzyme replacement therapy is also available.

Hypogammaglobulinemia (Option B): Only B-cell defect; ADA deficiency affects both B and T cells.

DiGeorge Syndrome (Option C): Caused by 22q11.2 deletion → thymic aplasia; not related to ADA metabolism.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (Option D): X-linked defect in WAS gene → eczema, thrombocytopenia, immunodeficiency; not due to purine metabolism defect.

 

Disease

Defect

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

Most commonly IL-2 receptor γ-chain (X-linked) or adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome

WAS protein defect (X-linked) — cytoskeletal reorganization in lymphocytes impaired

Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia

Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) defect (X-linked) — B-cell maturation failure

Hyper-IgM syndrome

CD40 ligand (CD40L) defect on T-cells (X-linked) — class switching defect

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)

NADPH oxidase defect — absent respiratory burst in neutrophils

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1

CD18 integrin subunit defect — defective leukocyte migration/chemotaxis

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

LYST (lysosomal trafficking regulator) defect — microtubule dysfunction in phagosome–lysosome fusion

DiGeorge syndrome

22q11 deletion — failure of 3rd/4th pharyngeal pouch development → absent thymus & parathyroids

Ataxia–telangiectasia

ATM gene defect — impaired DNA double-strand break repair

Complement (C1 esterase) inhibitor deficiency

C1 esterase inhibitor defect — hereditary angioedema

questions.text: A man kills his office colleague and later claims he was experiencing delusions of persecution and other psychotic features at the time of the act. He now asserts that he is not guilty by reason of insanity.What is the most appropriate next step under medico-legal protocol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Psychiatric evaluation

Explanation:

  • In medico-legal cases involving homicide, mental state assessment is the first step before legal proceedings.
  • The evaluation determines criminal responsibility and fitness to stand trial under mental health and legal standards.
  • This ensures that if the person was suffering from a mental disorder impairing judgment, the law can apply appropriate provisions.
  • Only after psychiatric evaluation can legal steps like trial or sentencing proceed.

Immediate trial of the case (Option B): Trials should only proceed after confirming the accused’s mental competence.

Declared not guilty (Option C): Requires psychiatric evidence and legal assessment, not the first step.

Sentenced for murder (Option D): Sentencing follows a completed trial and proof of guilt, not before evaluation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident and is found to have a closed midshaft fracture of the left tibia. Six hours later, he develops severe leg pain that is disproportionate to the injury and worsens with passive dorsiflexion of the foot. The pain is not relieved by analgesics. On examination, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present, but there is no sensation over the first dorsal webspace. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer opioid analgesics and continue observation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Immediate fasciotomy

Explanation:

  • Acute compartment syndrome (ACS) is a surgical emergency caused by raised intracompartmental pressure impairing perfusion.
  • Hallmark signs:
    • Severe, out-of-proportion pain.
    • Pain on passive stretch (earliest finding).
    • Sensory deficits (late sign) — here, loss over first dorsal webspace suggests deep peroneal nerve involvement.
    • Pulses usually present until late stages.
  • Management algorithm:
    • Positive clinical diagnosis → immediate fasciotomy without waiting for confirmatory tests.
    • In doubtful cases, measure intracompartmental pressure (ICP).
      • ICP > 30 mmHg → fasciotomy.
      • ICP < 30 mmHg → conservative measures.
  • Delay in fasciotomy risks irreversible muscle and nerve necrosis.

Elevate the limb and observe (Option A): Limb elevation above heart level can further reduce perfusion pressure and worsen ischemia in ACS; observation alone delays definitive management.

Administer opioid analgesics and continue observation (Option C): Analgesics do not treat the underlying ischemia; delaying fasciotomy can cause permanent damage within hours.

Apply cast and follow up (Option D): Applying a cast in suspected ACS is dangerous, as it can further increase compartment pressure and worsen ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell death involves activation of caspase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Apoptosis and Pyroptosis

Explanation:

Apoptosis and Pyroptosis involves activation of caspase enzymes.

Apoptosis

  • A tightly regulated suicide program where cells activate enzymes to degrade their DNA and proteins.
  • It’s an active process eliminating irreparably damaged cells without causing inflammation or tissue damage.
  • Driven by activation of caspases that cause DNA fragmentation
  • Phases: (Option B)
    • Initiation phase: Activation of caspases 8, 9, 10 triggers a cascade.
    • Execution phase: Terminal caspases 3, 6, 7 lead to cellular breakdown.
  • Morphological features:
    • Cell shrinkage
    • Chromatin condensation
    • Cytoplasmic blebs and formation of apoptotic bodies
    • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies by macrophages
  • Histopathology: Apoptotic cells appear as round/oval with intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm and dense nuclear chromatin fragments.

Pyroptosis

  • It is a form of programmed cell death involving release of IL-1, a fever-inducing cytokine.
  • Microbial products in cells activate the inflammasome complex.
  • Inflammasome activates caspase-1, which converts inactive IL-1 to active IL-1. (Option B)
  • Active IL-1 causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.
  • Pyroptosis helps eliminate infected cells and triggers local inflammation.

Necrosis (Option A) is a form of accidental cell death that does not involve caspases.

Necroptosis (Option C) is a programmed form of necrosis that occurs independently of caspases.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child with chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with bow legs. Laboratory investigations reveal:

Serum Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL (normal)

Serum Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL (elevated)

Alkaline Phosphatase: Elevated

25(OH) Vitamin D: Low

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Phosphate binder.

This child has CKD-related rickets/renal osteodystrophy, which occurs due to:

  • Hyperphosphatemia (due to reduced phosphate excretion in CKD)
  • Low active Vitamin D production (due to loss of renal 1α-hydroxylase activity)
  • Resulting secondary hyperparathyroidism → bone changes (e.g., bow legs)

Key lab clues in this case:

  • Normal serum calcium → indicates that hypocalcemia is not the primary driver at this stage
  • High serum phosphate → needs correction first to break the phosphate- PTH- bone cycle
  • Low 25(OH) Vitamin D → will also need correction, but not before controlling phosphate levels

First-line management:

  • Control phosphate with dietary restriction and phosphate binders (calcium carbonate or sevelamer) to prevent further hyperparathyroidism and bone damage.
  • Once phosphate is under control, give active vitamin D analogs (calcitriol/alfacalcidol) to correct the low vitamin D status.

Calcium supplementation (Option A): Not needed immediately since calcium is normal, and adding calcium without controlling phosphate can worsen vascular calcifications.

Oral calcium + Vitamin D (Option C): Will not address hyperphosphatemia and can worsen the phosphate load if the binder role is not addressed first.

Growth hormone therapy (Option D): Used in CKD-related short stature, but here the immediate issue is bone mineral disturbance, not growth failure management.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea for the past 8 months. Laboratory investigations reveal FSH of 36 IU/L and AMH of 0.05 ng/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI)

Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is premature ovarian insufficiency because this patient has elevated FSH (in menopausal range) and very low AMH, indicating ovarian follicular depletion.

Primary/Premature ovarian insufficiency (POI): Ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40.

  • It occurs due to a failure of germ cell migration or an accelerated rate of germ cell depletion during intrauterine life. This results in few or no follicles left in the ovary by puberty.
  • Ovarian biopsy is not essential to the diagnosis of premature ovarian insufficiency.

Causes of POI:

  • Genetic: Turner’s syndrome (45, XO), Fragile X syndrome
  • Iatrogenic: Chemotherapy, radiotherapy, ovarian surgery
  • Infectious: Mumps oophoritis, Autoimmune Oophoritis
  • Environmental: Smoking, Pesticides
  • FSH receptor abnormalities: Absent or defective FSH receptors, also known as Savage’s syndrome, the clinical features of it includes normal secondary sexual characteristics, regular female karyotype, and usual ovarian reserve, but elevated endogenous gonadotropin levels and low estrogen levels with primary or secondary amenorrhea).
  • Idiopathic

Management of POI:

  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): To prevent or minimize postmenopausal health risks
  • Corticosteroids: May be helpful in cases of autoimmune disorders
  • Ovulation induction: May be attempted in the presence of follicles using sequential estrogen and progesterone or a GnRH agonist followed by gonadotropins

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) (Option A): Usually has normal or mildly elevated LH/FSH, and AMH is often high due to increased antral follicles.

Hyperprolactinemia (Option B): Presents with galactorrhea and low/normal FSH; ovarian reserve markers are usually normal.

Hypothalamic amenorrhea (Option D): Associated with low gonadotropins (low FSH, LH) due to decreased hypothalamic GnRH secretion, not elevated FSH.

questions.text: A patient presents with morning stiffness and tests positive for anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following histological features is most characteristic of the underlying disease?

choices.text: Pannus formation and erosive joint damage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pannus formation and erosive joint damage

  • Anti-CCP antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The hallmark histopathological finding in RA is pannus formation - a hyperplastic granulation tissue composed of inflammatory cells, fibroblasts, and synovial cells, which invades cartilage and bone, leading to erosive joint damage and deformities.

Rheumatoid arthritis

Epidemiology

  • Male to female ratio - 1:3
  • Peaks between 25 and 55 years
  • Remains constant between 55 and 75

Genetics

  • Strongly associated with the HLA-DRβ1 gene
  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.
  • RA may remit during pregnancy and can first appear postpartum due to immune suppression and hormonal changes.

 

Non-caseating granulomas (Option B): Characteristic of sarcoidosis, not RA.

Subepidermal blister with IgA deposits (Option C): Seen in dermatitis herpetiformis, associated with celiac disease.

Tophi with monosodium urate crystals (Option D): Pathognomonic for chronic gout, not RA.

questions.text: A Patients presents with ankle pain and swelling after a forceful eversion injury. Based on the mechanism of injury, which ligament is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deltoid ligament

Explanation: A forceful eversion injury causes the foot to twist outward, placing stress on the medial structures of the ankle, most commonly resulting in damage to the Deltoid Ligament, the strong medial stabilizer of the joint.

  • A strong, fan-shaped ligament on the medial side of the ankle.
  • Composed of four parts:
    • Tibionavicular
    • Tibiocalcaneal
    • Posterior tibiotalar
    • Anterior tibiotalar
  • Function: Stabilizes the ankle joint and resists eversion forces.
    • Damage to this ligament can lead to medial ankle pain, swelling, and instability.
  • Injury (eversion):
    • Occur: Foot is forcefully twisted outward (away from the midline) → Stresses the medial (inner) side of the ankle.
    • Less common than inversion injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A : Anterior talofibular ligament is injured in inversion injuries, not eversion; part of the lateral ligament complex.

Option B: Calcaneofibular ligament is also part of the lateral side, damaged in inversion injuries.

Option D:Posterior talofibular ligament is rarely injured alone; involved in severe inversion injuries.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoing abdominal surgery under general anesthesia develops sudden generalized muscle rigidity, rapid increase in body temperature, and tachycardia shortly after administration of sevoflurane and succinylcholine. His end-tidal CO₂ is rising despite controlled ventilation. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dantrolene

Explanation: This patient has classic features of malignant hyperthermia - muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, tachycardia, and rising end-tidal CO₂ after exposure to triggering agents (volatile anesthetics like sevoflurane and succinylcholine).

  • The immediate and definitive treatment is intravenous dantrolene, a ryanodine receptor antagonist that inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, thereby reversing hypermetabolism and rigidity.
     

Triggers of Malignant Hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled general anesthetics
    • Ether
    • Halothane
    • Enflurane
    • Isoflurane
    • Desflurane
    • Sevoflurane
  • Depolarizing muscle relaxant
    • Succinylcholine
  • Prior exercise, even just an hour before anaesthesia induction, intensifies the severity and accelerates the onset of rigidity.

 

Initial Indicators of Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) During Anesthesia:

  • Muscle rigidity
  • Masseter spasm
  • Tachycardia
  • Unexplained hypercarbia
  • Increased temperature

Other Features: Cyanosis, metabolic acidosis, hypertension, fever, sweating, Hyperkalemia, Hyperphosphatemia, Myoglobinemia, Myoglobinuria, Cardiac Arrest, DIC, etc.

 

Diazepam (Option B): Benzodiazepine for seizures/muscle spasm, but ineffective in malignant hyperthermia.

Pancuronium (Option C): Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker; does not treat the underlying calcium dysregulation.

Vecuronium (Option D): Another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant; similarly ineffective in malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with bleeding manifestations. The peripheral smear shows the presence of the cells shown below. Which of the following is the most common chromosomal abnormality seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) t(15;17)

Explanation:

This patient's history of 68 year old man with bleeding manifestations and Auer-rods on blood smear suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to acute promyelocytic leukaemia associated with t(15:17) translocation.

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: FISH
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation; therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As2O3 (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

 

Incorrect Options:

t(8;21) (Option A): AML with maturation (FAB M2); often associated with large myeloblasts and abundant Auer rods, but not the classic multiple “faggot cell” picture of APL. It is associated with Chloroma.

t(14;18) (Option C): Follicular lymphoma; involves BCL2 gene rearrangement, unrelated to AML.

inv(16) (Option D): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils (FAB M4Eo), not APL.

questions.text: The time interval between acquiring an infection and reaching the period of maximum infectivity is known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Generation time:

Explanation:

  • Generation time is the period from the infection of a primary case to the time that case reaches maximum infectiousness, crucial for understanding transmission dynamics.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Communicable period is the duration during which the infected person can transmit infection.

Option C - Incubation period is from infection to onset of symptoms.

Option D - Serial interval is time between onset of symptoms in successive cases.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with white, dandruff-like deposits on the anterior lens surface, seen during slit-lamp examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

  • Based on the above findings,the patient has pseudoexfoliation syndrome, characterized by the deposition of whitish-gray, dandruff-like fibrillar material on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin. This appearance is also called the hoarfrost sign. The material is best seen after pupil dilation and often appears in a concentric ring pattern. It is strongly associated with secondary open-angle glaucoma due to blockage of the trabecular meshwork by exfoliated material and pigment.
  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related systemic condition with ocular manifestations involving abnormal production and accumulation of extracellular fibrillar material in ocular tissues. This is due to abnormal basement membrane metabolism → deposition of pseudoexfoliative material in anterior segment structures (lens capsule, iris, zonules, ciliary body).

Management: Regular IOP monitoring, antiglaucoma medications as needed, careful cataract surgery planning.

Iris cyst (Option B): Localized iris mass; does not cause diffuse frosted deposits on the lens capsule.

Persistent pupillary membrane (Option C): Remnant of tunica vasculosa lentis; appears as thin strands across the pupil, not concentric whitish deposits.

Pigment dispersion syndrome (Option D): Pigment granules deposited on corneal endothelium (Krukenberg’s spindle) and trabecular meshwork; lacks the characteristic fibrillar white deposits of pseudoexfoliation.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with a history of chronic ear drainage and hearing loss for several months. Otoscopic examination reveals a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Pure tone audiometry confirms a conductive hearing loss. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step in the definitive management of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Immediate commencement of broad-spectrum oral antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Myringoplasty:

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the most appropriate next step in definitive management is Myringoplasty.
  • Myringoplasty is the definitive surgical procedure aimed at closing the tympanic membrane perforation to restore the integrity of the middle ear and improve hearing. This is performed once the ear is dry and infection-free for at least 6–8 weeks.
  • The main techniques are underlay (graft placed under TM remnant, most common) and overlay (graft placed over TM remnant, used for anterior perforations). Common graft materials include temporalis fascia, tragal perichondrium, or cartilage. It restores hearing, prevents recurrent infections, and is considered Type I tympanoplasty.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Modified radical mastoidectomy is indicated in unsafe CSOM (atticoantral disease) or when there is cholesteatoma, granulations, or extensive disease involving the mastoid air cells.

Option C - Exploratory tympanostomy is performed primarily to assess and treat middle ear effusion, often in cases of otitis media with effusion (OME) or suspected hidden pathology.

Option D - Immediate commencement of broad-spectrum oral antibiotics may be needed for active discharge due to acute infection, but this is not definitive management.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with altered sensorium and deep labored breathing. ABG is given below. What is the most likely acid-base disorder?

pH: 7.20

pCO₂: 31 mmHg

HCO₃⁻:16 mEq/L

Na⁺: 130 mEq/L

Cl⁻: 84 mEq/L

PaO₂: 80 mmHg
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation: This ABG shows low pH (acidemia), low HCO₃⁻ (16 mEq/L), and compensatory low pCO₂ (31 mmHg) - the primary process is metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

  • The sodium and chloride values suggest a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (AG = Na⁺ − (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻) = 130 − (84 + 16) = 30 mEq/L), which could be due to causes like lactic acidosis, renal failure, ketoacidosis, or toxins.

 

Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

 

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis (Option C)
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B): Would have elevated pH and high HCO₃⁻, not low values.

Respiratory acidosis (Option C): Would show high pCO₂ and low pH, not low pCO₂.

Respiratory alkalosis (Option D): Would have high pH and low pCO₂, but here pH is low.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of hypertension presents with vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure her that this is normal at her age
Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound
Refer her to cardiology before any further evaluation
Start antihypertensives and observe for 1 week

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation: Immediate pelvic examination, Pap smear, and transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step, because, postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is never normal and should be treated as endometrial carcinoma until proven otherwise.

  • Hypertension is a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma, but it does not delay the need for prompt evaluation.
  • The initial work-up includes pelvic examination, Pap smear (for cervical pathology), and transvaginal ultrasound to assess endometrial thickness; an endometrial biopsy is indicated if thickness >4 mm or ultrasound is suspicious.

Reassure her that this is normal at her age (Option A): PMB is always pathological until proven otherwise. So, reassurance without evaluation risks missing malignancy.

Refer her to cardiology before any further evaluation (Option C): While hypertension should be addressed, it does not delay urgent gynecologic evaluation for PMB.

Start antihypertensives and observe for 1 week (Option D): Observation is inappropriate in PMB. Diagnostic work-up should be immediate.

questions.text: A new community intervention is initiated to reduce prenatal sepsis. Researchers allocate 20 Primary Health Centres (PHCs) to receive standard care and 20 PHCs to receive a community-based intervention. What type of study design is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cluster-randomized control trial

Explanation:

  • A cluster-randomized control trial randomizes groups (here PHCs) rather than individuals, evaluating intervention impact on communities or clusters, suitable for public health interventions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cross-sectional is observational at one time point.

Option B - Case-control is retrospective and individual-based.

Option C - Quasi-experimental lacks randomization, whereas this design includes it.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with heartburn, regurgitation, and post-meal bloating for the past 3 months. He is diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In addition to acid suppression, the physician decides to prescribe a drug that will enhance gastric emptying and esophageal motility to help relieve his symptoms. Which of the following drugs best serves this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Metoclopramide:

Explanation:

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that acts as a dopamine D₂ receptor antagonist and a 5-HT₄ receptor agonist.

  • ↑ LES tone: D₂ blockade increases acetylcholine release in the myenteric plexus → stronger contraction of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) → reduces reflux.
  • ↑ Gastric emptying: Enhances gastric peristalsis and relaxes the pyloric sphincter → less gastric stasis.
  • ↑ Upper GI motility: Improves coordination between stomach and duodenum without stimulating gastric acid secretion.

This makes it useful in GERD, gastroparesis (especially diabetic), and as an antiemetic in chemotherapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pantoprazole: This is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that potently suppresses gastric acid secretion by blocking the H+/K+ ATPase pump in gastric parietal cells. It is effective for acid suppression in GERD but does not enhance gastric emptying or esophageal motility.

Option C - Vonoprazan: A potassium-competitive acid blocker (P-CAB); like PPIs, it lowers acid production but has no prokinetic action.

Option D - Sodium alginate: Forms a viscous “raft” layer on gastric contents, reducing reflux episodes; purely a mechanical/physical barrier, not a motility enhancer.

questions.text: At point “C”, what is the length-tension relationship of the sarcomere
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -

Explanation:

The marked point on the graph represents Optimal Overlap, where actin and myosin filaments align ideally, enabling the maximum number of cross-bridges to form; therefore, option D is the most accurate.

  • Optimal overlap refers to the ideal length of a muscle sarcomere where the maximum number of actin and myosin cross-bridges can form, resulting in maximal force generation during contraction.

The length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle:

  • Optimal Length: The sarcomere length that produces maximum tension is between 2.0 and 2.2 μm.

  • Cross-Bridge Formation: Tension is greatest at this optimal length because cross-bridge formation between actin and myosin filaments is maximized.

  • Short Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are shorter than optimal, excessive overlap of actin filaments limits cross-bridge formation, reducing tension.

  • Long Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are longer than optimal, cross-bridge formation decreases as actin and myosin filaments overlap less, leading to reduced tension.

  • Maximum Stretch: At lengths around 3.6 μm, the sarcomere can rupture due to excessive stretching.

questions.text: Patient came with severe headache and seizures. Sodium on admission was 98 meq/L. We have started correction with 3% saline and now after 24 hours of infusion sodium is 110 meq/L. Patient develops mutism and altered sensorium. Which investigation will you perform now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI Head

Explanation: MRI Head is done because this patient likely developed Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (Central Pontine Myelinolysis) due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.

  • Safe correction: ≤ 8–10 mEq/L in 24 hours.
  • Here, sodium increased by 12 mEq/L in 24 hrs → high risk of demyelination.
  • Symptoms of ODS: mutism, quadriparesis, pseudobulbar palsy, altered consciousness.
  • MRI brain is the investigation of choice

LP for CSF biochemistry (Option B): Not useful; ODS is not an infectious/inflammatory process and CSF is typically normal.

Brainstem evoked potentials (Option C): May detect conduction abnormalities but is not first-line for diagnosis.

EEG (Option D): May show nonspecific slowing in encephalopathy, but will not confirm ODS.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases exhibits the inheritance pattern shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Explanation:

  • The pattern shown in the pedigree is Mitochondrial Inheritance, which is characteristic of Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited solely maternally. Thus, females with causative mtDNA may transmit the disease to all offspring. However, the disease's expression is variable due to heteroplasmy (the combination of both mutant and wild DNA in offspring).
  • Mitochondrial diseases thus affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism. Skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system involvement are common.

Some other examples are:

  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS)
  • Leigh syndrome (Option A)
  • Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)
  • Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF)
  • Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP)
  • Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency

Incorrect Options:

Williams syndrome (Option B) is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 7, it follows an autosomal dominant pattern, not mitochondrial inheritance.

Achondroplasia (Option C) is a result of a mutation in the FGFR3 gene, achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and does not involve mitochondrial DNA.

Cystic fibrosis (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations in the CFTR gene, cystic fibrosis is inherited via nuclear DNA, not mitochondria.

questions.text: During a full-term vaginal delivery, an obstetrics resident is seen applying counterpressure above the pubic symphysis with one hand while gently pulling on the umbilical cord with the other. Which maneuver is being demonstrated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Controlled cord traction

Explanation:

  • The above history and image is suggestive of controlled cord traction (CCT)
  • Controlled cord traction (CCT) is a key step in the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). One hand applies counterpressure above the pubic symphysis to stabilize the uterus and prevent uterine inversion. The other hand gently pulls on the umbilical cord in a downward and outward direction to facilitate delivery of the placenta.
  • CCT is performed only after signs of placental separation (gush of blood, cord lengthening, uterine fundus rising and becoming globular).

Active Management of Third Stage of Labour (AMTSL)

  • Uterotonic administration — Give Oxytocin 10 IU IM (preferred) within 1 minute of baby’s delivery.
  • Controlled cord traction (CCT) — Apply gentle, steady traction on the umbilical cord with counter-pressure on the uterus (Brandt–Andrews maneuver).
  • Uterine massage — After delivery of placenta, massage the uterus to maintain contraction.
  • Early cord clamping and cutting — Within 1–3 minutes after birth (delayed clamping preferred unless contraindicated).

Manual removal of placenta (Option B): Indicated only in retained placenta after 30 minutes or when there is severe bleeding. It is more invasive, with higher infection and trauma risk.

Uterine massage (Option C): Used after placenta delivery to maintain uterine tone and prevent atony.

Bimanual uterine compression (Option D): One hand compresses the uterus externally while the other is inside the vagina pushing against the anterior fornix done in the management of PPH not for placental delivery.

questions.text: A55 y/o man is undergoing general anaesthesia for abdominal pain and surgery. Shortly after administration of a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker, he develops bronchospasm, hypotension and flushing of the face. Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants is most likely responsible for this reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atracurium

Explanation: The patient’s presentation of flushing and rash over the neck and chest during surgery is due to histamine release from a muscle relaxant.

  • Atracurium is known for causing histamine release, which can lead to flushing, hypotension, and bronchospasm in sensitive individuals.
  • This reaction is dose-related and occurs more commonly with atracurium than with other neuromuscular blockers.

Cisatracurium (Option B): Stereoisomer of atracurium, but much less histamine release; preferred in patients at risk.

Vecuronium (Option C): Minimal cardiovascular or histamine effects.

Pancuronium (Option D): Causes vagolytic effects (↑HR), no significant histamine release.

questions.text: Complementary feeding is initiated for a 7-month-old infant using the “katori method”. What is the recommended amount and frequency of food to be given in the first 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. ½–1 katori, 4 times a day

  • Complementary feeding starts at 6 months while continuing breastfeeding. For a 7-month-old, the recommend amount and frequency of food given in the first 24 hours is ½–1 katori per feed, 4 times/day, plus breastfeeding on demand.
  • Complementary feeding ensures adequate nutrition after exclusive breastfeeding period ends. Foods should be soft, mashed, and energy dense (e.g., dal, mashed fruits, khichdi). Gradual increase in amount and variety prevents feeding difficulties and nutritional deficiencies.
  • ½–1 katori, 5/ 6 /7 times/day (Other options): Exceeds recommended frequency and may cause digestive issues. Feeding so frequently is impractical and unnecessary for nutrient needs at this stage.

questions.text: A patient with HIV is newly diagnosed with multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Which of the following is the appropriate regimen, and what should the patient be monitored for?

choices.text: BPaLM; monitor for immune reconstitution syndrome
INH + Levofloxacin + Pyrazinamide + ethambutol, monitor for hepatotoxicity
INH + Levofloxacin + Streptomycin + Ethionamide, monitor for pyridoxine deficiency
INH + Clarithromycin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol, monitor for optic neuritis

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - BPaLM; monitor for immune reconstitution syndrome

Explanation:

BPaLM is the WHO-recommended short, all-oral regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), especially in HIV-positive patients:

  • B → Bedaquiline

  • Pa → Pretomanid

  • L → Linezolid

  • M → Moxifloxacin

It is all-oral, avoids injectables, and is given for 6–9 months, replacing the older 18–20 month MDR-TB regimens.

IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome):

  • In HIV + TB, starting ART can lead to immune recovery and an exaggerated inflammatory response against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

  • This paradoxical worsening is IRIS.

  • MDR-TB patients on potent regimens like BPaLM are at higher risk if ART is initiated or intensified.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - INH + Levofloxacin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol; monitor for hepatotoxicity: INH resistance is part of MDR-TB (MDR-TB is resistant to at least INH + Rifampicin). INH is therefore ineffective here.

Option C - INH + Levofloxacin + Streptomycin + Ethionamide; monitor for pyridoxine deficiency: Still contains INH → ineffective for MDR-TB. Streptomycin is no longer routinely used due to toxicity and low efficacy against MDR strains.

Option D - INH + Clarithromycin + Pyrazinamide + Ethambutol; monitor for optic neuritis (Option D): Clarithromycin is used in MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex), not MDR-TB first-line. INH again makes this regimen inappropriate for MDR-TB.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of chronic meningitis. Laboratory findings show Gram-positive, filamentous branching bacteria, Positive ZN stain, and Growth on paraffin bait culture. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nocardia asteroides

Explanation:

Nocardia:

  • Morphology: Gram-positive, branching, filamentous rods.
  • Acid-fast property: Weakly acid-fast due to mycolic acids in cell wall (detected by modified Ziehl–Neelsen stain).
  • Habitat: Soil organism, opportunistic pathogen.
  • Diseases: Can cause chronic lung disease, brain abscess, and meningitis, especially in immunocompromised patients.
  • Unique culture feature: Grows on paraffin bait medium.

Actinomyces israelii (Option A): Gram-positive branching bacteria but not acid-fast and does not grow on paraffin bait; causes cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option B): Acid-fast bacilli, not branching filamentous bacteria; does not grow on paraffin bait.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option D): Encapsulated yeast, detected with India ink, not Gram-positive filamentous bacteria.

questions.text: A 43 year old female present to OPD due changes in breast changes in breast and a lump in breast as given below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T4b

Explanation: The given image depicts Peau d orange appearance which corresponds to T4b.

In TNM staging for breast cancer:

  • T4b includes skin changes such as ulceration, ipsilateral satellite skin nodules, or edema including peau d’orange, not involving the entire breast.

TNM staging for breast cancer

Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules or Peau d orange

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

Stage Grouping

Stage 0: Tis N0 M0

Stage IA: T1/T1mi N0 M0

Stage IB: T0 N1mi M0; T1/T1mi N1mi M0

Stage IIA: T0 N1 M0; T1 N1 M0; T2 N0 M0

Stage IIB: T2 N1 M0; T3 N0 M0

Stage IIIA: T0 N2 M0; T1 N2 M0; T2 N2 M0; T3 N1 M0

Stage IIIB: T3 N2 M0

Stage IIIC: T4 N0 M0; T4 N1 M0; T4 N2 M0; Any T N3 M0

Stage IV: Any T Any N M1

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed with a pituitary microadenoma and has elevated serum prolactin levels. She presents with secondary amenorrhea and infertility. What is the most likely mechanism by which hyperprolactinemia causes these symptoms?

choices.text: Decreased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus
Increased LH secretion from the pituitary

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decreased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus

Explanation: Hyperprolactinemia suppresses hypothalamic GnRH release via inhibitory effects on the hypothalamic dopaminergic pathway. This leads to reduced FSH and LH secretion from the anterior pituitary, causing anovulation, amenorrhea, and infertility.

  • Prolactinomas cause amenorrhea + galactorrhea in women and hypogonadism + erectile dysfunction in men. Dopamine agonists like cabergoline or bromocriptine are first-line treatments.

Antagonism of estrogen receptors (Option A): This is the mechanism of drugs like clomiphene citrate, not hyperprolactinemia.

Increased pulsatile FSH secretion (Option C): In hyperprolactinemia, FSH secretion is decreased, not increased.

Increased LH secretion from the pituitary (Option D): LH secretion is also reduced due to low GnRH, not elevated.

questions.text: Identify the fistula according to park’s classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intersphincteric

Explanation: The given image depicts Intersphincteric fistula.

Parks classification:

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: A child presents with developmental delay and coarse facial features. Enzyme assay reveals a deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. Which of the following substances is most likely to accumulate in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Dermatan sulfate + Heparan sulfate

  • α-L-iduronidase deficiency → Hurler syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis type I). This enzyme is required to degrade dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Deficiency → accumulation of both in lysosomes → progressive multisystem disease.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by α-L-iduronidase deficiency. This enzyme normally cleaves terminal iduronic acid residues in dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. Failure to degrade these glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) → lysosomal storage in multiple tissues.

Clinical features:

  • developmental delay, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, joint stiffness, skeletal abnormalities.
  • Progressive neurodegeneration occurs due to GAG accumulation in the CNS.

MPS Type

Disease Name

Enzyme Deficiency

Accumulating GAG(s)

MPS I

Hurler syndrome

α-L-iduronidase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate

MPS II

Hunter syndrome

Iduronate sulfatase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate

MPS III

Sanfilippo syndrome

Multiple enzyme defects

Heparan sulfate

MPS IV

Morquio syndrome

Galactosamine-6-sulfatase or β-galactosidase

Keratan sulfate

MPS VI

Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome

Arylsulfatase B

Dermatan sulfate

MPS VII

Sly syndrome

β-glucuronidase

Dermatan sulfate, Heparan sulfate, Chondroitin sulfate

Management:

  • ↑ urinary excretion of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate; confirmed by enzyme assay.
  • Management is supportive ± enzyme replacement therapy (laronidase).

Dermatan sulfate + Chondroitin sulfate (Option A)- Chondroitin sulfate is not a substrate for α-L-iduronidase; it’s degraded by other enzymes.

Only Dermatan sulfate (Option B) is incorrect because α-L-iduronidase also acts on heparan sulfate; both accumulate.

Heparan sulfate + Chondroitin sulfate (Option D)- Chondroitin sulfate is not involved in Hurler syndrome; dermatan sulfate is the correct partner with heparan sulfate.

questions.text: A study is conducted to compare the mean hemoglobin (Hb) levels between two independent groups. Which statistical test is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Unpaired t-test

Explanation:

  • An unpaired t-test (also called an independent samples t-test) is used when:
    • The outcome variable is continuous (e.g., hemoglobin levels).
    • There are two separate, independent groups being compared.
    • The data is approximately normally distributed in both groups, and variances are equal (or adjustments are made if not).
    • This test determines whether the observed difference in means is statistically significant, beyond what might occur due to random variation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paired t-test: Used for matched or related samples — such as pre- and post-treatment measurements in the same subjects, or matched pairs. Not suitable for unrelated groups.

Option C - Chi-square test: Compares categorical data frequencies, not continuous numerical means.

Option D - ANOVA : Compares means for three or more independent groups; not needed when only two groups are being compared.

questions.text: A male patient presents with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid examination shows septate hyphae with acute angle (dichotomous) branching under microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Aspergillosis

Explanation:

  • Aspergillus species (most commonly A. fumigatus) produce thin, septate hyphae with acute angle branching (~45°), a hallmark microscopic finding.
  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis occurs primarily in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., neutropenia, post-transplant, prolonged corticosteroid use).
  • Clinically, it presents with fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis due to vascular invasion.
  • BAL cytology and special stains (Gomori methenamine silver, PAS) confirm diagnosis.

Mucormycosis (Option A) shows broad, nonseptate hyphae with obtuse branching and tends to invade blood vessels aggressively.

Histoplasmosis (Option B) is a dimorphic fungus existing mostly as intracellular yeast in human tissue, thus hyphae are not observed in BAL fluid .

Candidiasis (Option D) usually involves budding yeast and pseudohyphae rather than true septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

questions.text: In the “De facto” method of census data collection, information is collected based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Location at time of enumeration

Explanation:

  • The de facto census method counts individuals based on where they are physically located at the time of the census, regardless of their usual place of residence.
  • It is particularly useful for capturing transient populations, travelers, or people temporarily away from home.
  • This approach ensures that everyone present in a given location is recorded at the same moment, but it can lead to discrepancies when compared with the de jure method, which uses the place of usual residence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Place of birth: Records where a person was born — this is a demographic variable, not a census enumeration method.

Option C - Usual residence: This is the de jure method, which counts individuals at the place they normally live, regardless of their physical presence on census day — different from the de facto approach.

Option D - Place of employment: Refers to occupational data collection for workforce statistics, not the basis for population counting in a census.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with painless vaginal bleeding. She has no history of hormone replacement therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endometrial carcinoma

Explanation: Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is the most common presenting symptom of malignancy, and any PMB should be considered carcinoma until proven otherwise.

Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is defined as vaginal bleeding that occurs 12 months or more after the cessation of menstruation.

Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • LYNCH syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Early menarche
  • Late menopause
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNG-IUS

Adenomyosis (Option B): Typically affects women of reproductive age and presents with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and a tender, bulky uterus & not postmenopausal bleeding.

Uterine fibroid (Option C): Usually causes heavy menstrual bleeding during reproductive years; postmenopausal fibroids typically shrink and rarely cause bleeding unless degenerating.

Endometriosis (Option D): Disease of reproductive-age women associated with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility & not a cause of PMB.

questions.text: In the repair of a mediolateral episiotomy, what is the correct order of tissue closure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mucosa → Muscle → Skin

Explanation: The correct sequence is mucosa → muscle → skin because repair begins from the vaginal mucosa to restore the integrity of the birth canal, followed by approximation of the perineal muscles to restore pelvic floor support, and finally closure of the skin to complete the repair and promote healing.

  • This sequence also ensures proper hemostasis and anatomical alignment.

Episiotomy repair:

  • Timing:
    • Done soon after the expulsion of the placenta to prevent wound disruption and reduce the risk of infection (sepsis).
    • Early repair also helps alleviate patient discomfort and anxiety about sutures.
  • Order of repair:
    • Vaginal mucosa and submucosa
    • Perineal muscles
    • Skin and subcutaneous tissue

Layer

Description

Vaginal Mucosa and Submucosal Tissues
  • Sutured starting at or above the apex of the tear.
  • Interrupted sutures with Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) or No. '0' Chromic Catgut.

Perineal Muscles
  • Absorbable sutures like Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) or Chromic Catgut.

Skin and Subcutaneous Tissues
  • Absorbable or non-absorbable sutures depending on preference and wound characteristics.

Types of episiotomy:

 

Type

Advantages

Disadvantages

Mediolateral
  • Reduced risk of severe perineal tears.
  • May facilitate easier delivery.
  • Less risk of injury to the anal sphincter compared to the midline.
  • Higher risk of postpartum pain and discomfort.
  • Potential for increased blood loss compared to other types.
  • It may not be suitable for all cases, depending on perineal anatomy.

Median
  • Simplicity in execution.
  • Reduced risk of injury to the anal sphincter.
  • Less postoperative pain compared to mediolateral.
  • Higher risk of severe perineal tears, including anal sphincter injury.
  • Potential for increased healing time and complications due to midline orientation.

Lateral/
Transverse
  • Potential for reducing the risk of severe perineal tears compared to midline.
  • Less disruption to perineal body alignment.
  • May be quicker to perform in some cases.
  • Higher risk of complications such as Bartholin's duct injury.
  • Increased likelihood of uneven wound healing.
  • Not preferred due to the potential for structural damage and poor cosmetic outcomes.

T-shaped
  • Potential for minimising anal sphincter injury.
  • May provide better vaginal opening in complex deliveries.
  • Less risk of perineal tear extension.
  • Complex to perform.
  • Likely to cause puckering and imperfect wound closure.
  • Not widely recommended due to the potential for postoperative complications and difficult repair.

questions.text: Identify the structure on AP barium swallow
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pyriform fossa

  • The AP barium swallow image shows bilateral contrast-filled recesses lateral to the laryngeal inlet. These are characteristic of the pyriform fossae (also called piriform sinuses), which are pharyngeal recesses on each side of the laryngeal orifice.

Pyriform Fossa:

  • Part of the laryngopharynx (hypopharynx).
  • Lies on each side of the laryngeal inlet.
  • Shaped like an inverted tear-drop recess.
  • Bounded by:
    • Medially: Aryepiglottic fold + laryngeal inlet.
    • Laterally: Thyroid cartilage & thyrohyoid membrane.
    • Posteriorly: Pharyngeal wall.

Clinical Significance:

  • Foreign body impaction: Fish bones often lodge here → pain & risk of mucosal injury.
  • Cancer: Hypopharyngeal cancers often start in pyriform fossa → late presentation.
  • Surgical importance: Care to avoid injury to internal laryngeal nerve during endoscopic removal.

Epiglottis (Option B): Midline structure, not paired; appears as a thin flap, not recesses.

Vallecula (Option C): Between base of tongue & epiglottis, higher up than the structures seen here.

Thyroid cartilage (Option D): Skeletal framework, not contrast-filled space.

questions.text: Under the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) scheme, what is the composition of IFA tablets given to children aged 10–19 years?

choices.text: 60 mg elemental iron + 100 µg folic acid
100 mg elemental iron + 500 µg folic acid
100 mg elemental iron + 100 µg folic acid
60 mg elemental iron + 500 µg folic acid

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 60 mg elemental iron + 500 µg folic acid:

Explanation:

  • The WIFS program recommends weekly supplementation to adolescents with 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 µg (0.5 mg) of folic acid to prevent and control anemia effectively in this age group.
  • Lower folic acid doses (Option A) are insufficient; higher iron doses (Options B and C) are typically used in therapeutic daily supplementation, not weekly prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a non-progressive hypopigmented lesion on the trunk. On Wood’s lamp examination, there is white accentuation. Diasoscopy is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nevus depigmentosus

Explanation:

  • Nevus depigmentosus is a congenital, stable, non-progressive hypopigmented macule or patch, present from early life.
  • Lesion is usually solitary, well-defined, and does not spread over time.
  • Wood’s lamp shows an off-white accentuation (less bright than vitiligo).
  • Diascopy is negative because the hypopigmentation is due to reduced melanin, not vascular changes.
  • No sensory loss or scaling is present.
  • Management is generally reassurance; no effective repigmentation treatment is required unless for cosmetic concerns.

Vitiligo (Option A): An acquired progressive depigmentation with complete loss of melanin; Wood’s lamp shows bright chalk-white fluorescence; lesions tend to enlarge over time.
 

Nevus anemicus (Option C): A vascular anomaly where skin appears pale due to localized increased vasoconstriction; diascopy causes the lesion to blend with surrounding skin (positive diascopy), unlike nevus depigmentosus.
 

Indeterminate leprosy (Option D): Hypopigmented patch with impaired sensation and possible nerve thickening; would not be stable for years without progression, and diagnosis requires sensory loss or skin smear evidence.

questions.text: Hyperpigmentation in Addison’s disease is due to increased secretion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ACTH

In primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease), destruction of the adrenal cortex leads to low cortisol and aldosterone. The pituitary compensates by secreting more ACTH from the precursor proopiomelanocortin (POMC), which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

  • MSH stimulates melanin production, causing skin and mucosal hyperpigmentation.

Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure:

Etiology

  • Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide
    • Sporadic
    • Polyglandular syndromes
  • Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India
  • Histoplasmosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Bilateral adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency
    • Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (dilutional), hypercalcemia
