  • Mineralocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Hypotension, shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • ACTH excess: Pigmentation
  • Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females

Cortisol (Option A): Deficient in Addison’s disease; low levels stimulate ACTH production but do not directly cause pigmentation.

Aldosterone (Option C): Deficient in Addison’s disease; loss leads to hyperkalemia and hypotension, not pigmentation.

Renin (Option D): Elevated due to hypovolemia, but has no role in pigmentation.

questions.text: A patient presents with an indurated plaque on the cheek with central atrophy. Chest X-ray reveals apical calcification. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PCR

Explanation:

  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, often arising from hematogenous or lymphatic spread from a latent pulmonary focus.
  • Clinical clue: indurated plaque with central atrophy on the face + old TB lesion in the lung (apical calcification).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA is the most sensitive and specific test to confirm cutaneous TB.
  • PCR detects bacterial DNA even when bacillary load is low (as in lupus vulgaris, which is paucibacillary).
  • While Mantoux may support diagnosis, it is not confirmatory

Lupus vulgaris

  • Chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (M/C in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.

 

Pathogenesis :

  • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
  • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins.
  • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules.
  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.
  • Diagnosis is often confirmed by histopathological examination of skin biopsy specimens, which typically show caseating granulomas with acid-fast bacilli.

The above image depicts the Apple Jelly Nodule

Complication:

  • Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

Treatment :

  • Anti-tubercular drugs.

Mantoux test (Option A): Indicates prior sensitization to TB but cannot confirm active disease; may be positive in BCG-vaccinated individuals and other mycobacterial infections.

Slit skin smear (Option B): Useful for detecting acid-fast bacilli in leprosy, not for cutaneous TB where bacillary load is very low.

Probe test (Option D): Used in oral submucous fibrosis to assess fibrous bands in the oral mucosa; not related to lupus vulgaris diagnosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient is currently on Metformin and Insulin Glargine. His HbA1c is 8.2%, indicating suboptimal glycemic control. Echocardiography reveals a reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 35%. Which of the following is the most appropriate agent to add to his current regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Empagliflozin

Explanation: Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that not only lowers blood glucose but also has proven cardiovascular benefits, particularly in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), irrespective of diabetes status.

  • In this diabetic patient with suboptimal glycemic control and EF 35%, empagliflozin is the preferred add-on as it reduces hospitalizations for heart failure and improves survival.

Pioglitazone (Option A): Causes fluid retention and can worsen heart failure — contraindicated in EF <40%.

Glimepiride (Option B): A sulfonylurea that increases hypoglycemia risk and offers no cardiovascular benefit.

Sitagliptin (Option C): A DPP-4 inhibitor with neutral cardiovascular effects; not first choice for HFrEF.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to evaluate the underlying immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Terminal complement (C5–C9) assay

Explanation:

  • Deficiency of the terminal complement pathway (C5–C9) impairs the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), which is essential for direct lysis of Neisseria species.
  • Patients remain otherwise immunologically normal but are prone to recurrent, often disseminated infections by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • A functional or quantitative assay of C5–C9 confirms the diagnosis.

C1 esterase inhibitor assay is used to diagnose hereditary angioedema, unrelated to infections (Option A).

Quantitative immunoglobulin levels assess antibody-mediated immunity but do not specifically predict susceptibility to Neisseria (Option B).

Nitroblue tetrazolium test diagnoses chronic granulomatous disease by assessing neutrophil oxidative burst, unrelated here (Option C).

questions.text: A diabetic patient with COVID-19 dies in the hospital. Which type of surveillance does this death report fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Passive surveillance

Explanation:

  • In passive surveillance, healthcare providers routinely submit reports to public health authorities based on diagnosed cases or events they encounter in daily practice.
  • A hospital death certificate for a diabetic patient with COVID-19 is an example — the hospital records the death and reports it to health authorities without special prompting or additional case-finding efforts.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Active surveillance: Involves actively seeking out cases through field visits, record reviews, or outreach by public health officials — more resource-intensive and not part of routine passive reporting.

Option C - Sentinel surveillance: Relies on selected health facilities or sites to provide high-quality, detailed data for certain conditions, often for trend monitoring — not a universal reporting system.

Option D - Syndromic surveillance: Focuses on early detection by monitoring symptom patterns (e.g., fever, cough) before a definitive diagnosis is made — this case already has a confirmed cause of death.

questions.text: A schizophrenia patient on haoperidol was responding well for last 2 years. Now presented with involuntary mouth and lip movements (perioral dyskinesia), choreiform, and tick-like movements and possible dystonia. What is the probable diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tardive dyskinesia – valbenazine:

Explanation:

  • The scenario is diagnosed as medication-induced Tardive dyskinesia, for which the drug of choice is Valbenazine.

Tardive dyskinesia

Description

A delayed effect (abnormal involuntary movements) of antipsychotics typically occurs until after 6 months of treatment.

Cause

Supersensitization of dopamine (D) receptors due to prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medications.

Manifestations

Abnormal, involuntary movements such as:

  • Lip smacking
  • Chewing
  • Darting, twisting, and protrusion of the tongue (catching fly)
  • Choreiform hand movements (playing piano)
  • Facial grimacing
  • Finger movements and hand clenching

In Severe cases:

  • Torticollis (twisting of neck muscles to one side)
  • Retrocollis (neck extension)
  • Trunk twisting
  • Pelvic thrusting

Management

Prevention: Using antipsychotic medications only when indicated and in the lowest effective doses.

Regular monitoring: Patients taking antipsychotics should be regularly assessed for any signs of abnormal movements.

Treatment:

  • Reducing antipsychotic drugs (or stop if possible)
  • Switching the medication to clozapine (least EPS-causing) or atypical antipsychotics
  • VMAT (Vesicular Monoamine Transporter type 2) receptor inhibitor:
    • Valbenazine (drug of choice)
    • Tetrabenazine- Lesser efficacy, more sedation than Valbenazine

 Incorrect Options:

Option A: Acute dystonia - ropinirole - Acute dystonia (muscle spasms, torticollis, oculogyric crisis) occurs hours–days after starting an antipsychotic. It is treated with anticholinergics (benztropine, diphenhydramine), not dopamine agonists like ropinirole. Ropinirole would worsen psychosis.

Option C: Akathisia – propranolol - Akathisia (subjective restlessness, inability to stay still) is indeed treated with β-blockers (propranolol) or benzodiazepines.But our patient has TD, not akathisia.

Option D: Parkinsonism – benztropine- This patient has abnormal involuntary movements, not rigidity/bradykinesia/tremor, hence, even though benztropine is the drug of choice for drug-induced Parkisonism, it is does not fit the clinical diagnosis for the above mentioned clinical features.

questions.text: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act covers which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - All children below 18 years

Explanation:

  • The POCSO Act, 2012 provides a gender-neutral legal framework to protect all children (boys and girls) under the age of 18 years from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and exploitation.
  • The Act clearly defines a “child” as any person below 18 years.
  • Protection is irrespective of gender or consent in cases involving minors.
  • Other options narrow protection incorrectly by gender or age.

questions.text: A 15-year-old tall boy with long limbs presents to the OPD. On ocular examination, bilateral ectopia lentis is noted. Which gene is most likely affected in this inherited disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. FBN1 (Fibrillin-1)

  • Bilateral ectopia lentis in a tall individual with long limbs is classic for Marfan syndrome, which is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15.
  • Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.
  • Pathophysiology: Defective fibrillin leads to abnormal connective tissue elasticity and excess TGF-β activation.

Clinical features

  • Ocular features: Ectopia lentis (usually superotemporal lens subluxation), myopia, risk of retinal detachment.
  • Skeletal features: Tall stature, arachnodactyly, long limbs (dolichostenomelia), pectus deformities, scoliosis.
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic root dilation, aneurysm, aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse—major cause of mortality.

Management: Regular cardiovascular monitoring, beta-blockers or ARBs to slow aortic dilation, surgical repair when needed.

COL5A (Option A) mutations cause Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (classic type), presenting with hyperextensible skin, hypermobile joints, and poor wound healing, not isolated ectopia lentis.

PAX6 (Option B) is associated with aniridia and other anterior segment dysgenesis disorders, not Marfan syndrome.

TGFβR2 (Option C) mutations cause Loeys–Dietz syndrome, which shares aortic aneurysms with Marfan’s but usually has hypertelorism, bifid uvula, and no typical lens dislocation.

questions.text: During a Health Mela organized by a medical college, the Nalgonda technique for water purification was demonstrated. Which two chemicals are used in this technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alum and Lime

Explanation:

  • The Nalgonda technique is a simple, cost-effective, and scalable method for defluoridation of drinking water, developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI), Nagpur.
  • It uses alum (aluminum sulfate) as a coagulant to flocculate and settle suspended impurities and lime to adjust the pH, enhance coagulation, and facilitate precipitation of fluorides.
  • This method is widely used in rural and community settings due to its low cost and ease of implementation.
  • In full-scale defluoridation, LAB (Lime, Alum, Bleaching powder) is added for combined purification and disinfection.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines will you use in the clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Use A and B:

Explanation:

Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM):

  • Purpose:
    • A heat-sensitive label on vaccine vials to ensure vaccine potency during transportation and storage.
  • Function:
    • The VVM contains a heat-sensitive material that changes colour irreversibly when exposed to heat over time.
    • Healthcare providers use this visual indicator to assess if a vaccine has been exposed to inappropriate temperatures.
  • Usage Criteria:
    • The vaccine is usable if the inner square of the VVM is lighter than the outer circle. (Option B)
    • The vaccine should be discarded if the inner square is the same colour as or darker than the outer circle.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is undergoing a vaginal breech delivery. After delivering the baby’s body up to the umbilicus, the obstetrician notices winging of the baby’s scapula. To facilitate safe delivery of the baby’s shoulders and head, which of the following maneuvers is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lovset maneuver

Explanation: In vaginal breech delivery, winging of the scapula indicates that the arms are extended above the head (nuchal arms). The Lovset maneuver is specifically designed to deliver the extended arms by rotating the baby’s body to bring each shoulder anterior under the symphysis pubis, allowing gentle sweeping down of the arms.

Lovset maneuver: In a vaginal breech delivery scenario where one of the baby's arms is extended behind the fetal head, causing difficulty in delivery, the technique typically used to manage this situation is Lovset's manoeuvre.

  • Principle: Due to the curved birth canal, one shoulder remains above the pubic bone while the other is below the sacral promontory. Rotating the fetal trunk with the back anterior and applying downward traction brings the posterior shoulder below the symphysis pubis.
  • Procedure: Lift the baby, induce lateral flexion, rotate the trunk 180° to bring the posterior arm under the pubic arch, and hook out. Rotate the trunk opposite, keeping the back anterior, to deliver the anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

 

 

Pinard's manoeuvre (Option A):

  • This maneuver resolves shoulder dystocia by applying pressure to the anterior shoulder to rotate it internally or manipulate it for delivery.
  • It may be used in some breech deliveries but is not specifically for managing extended arms.

 

Burns Marshall maneuver (Option B):

  • It is used in breech presentation to deliver the after-coming head.
  • The baby hangs by its weight while suprapubic pressure is applied downward and backward.
  • Once the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby's ankles are grasped, and steady traction is applied in an upward and forward arc. Simultaneously, the left hand supports the perineum and guides it gently over the face and brow.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique (Option D) :

The obstetrician supports the baby's head with the palm, and the index finger is placed inside the baby's mouth to support the mandible. Traction is applied to the baby's shoulders to guide the head through the birth canal.

questions.text: A woman presents for her first antenatal visit and reports that her LMP was approximately 2 months ago. Which ultrasound parameter is the most accurate for dating the pregnancy at this stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Crown-rump length

Explanation: The most accurate is crown–rump length (CRL) because between 7–13 weeks gestation, CRL is the most accurate parameter for dating a pregnancy.

  • At 2 months (~8 weeks), the embryo is clearly visible, and CRL gives a precise measurement from the top of the head to the bottom of the buttocks, unaffected by growth variations.

Dating accuracy by parameter:

  • <6–7 weeks → Mean gestational sac diameter
  • 7–13 weeks → Crown–rump length (most accurate overall)
  • 14–20 weeks → Biparietal diameter
  • Late pregnancy → Multiple parameters (BPD, HC, AC, FL)

Biparietal diameter (Option A): Most accurate from 14–20 weeks; not the best choice this early.

Mean gestational sac diameter (Option B): Used before the embryo is visible (<6–7 weeks); less accurate than CRL once the embryo is measurable.

Abdominal circumference (Option C): Used in the second and third trimesters to estimate fetal weight, not for early pregnancy dating.

questions.text: A patient presents with orange-colored tonsils. Laboratory investigations reveal triglyceride level of 140 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol of 5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tangier disease

Explanation:

  • The presence of orange-colored tonsils, extremely low HDL cholesterol (5 mg/dL), and normal triglyceride levels (140 mg/dL) are hallmark features of Tangier Disease, a rare inherited disorder of lipid metabolism.

Incorrect Options:

Familial hypercholesterolemia (Option A) is characterized by high LDL cholesterol, not low HDL, and typically presents with tendon xanthomas, not orange-colored tonsils.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia (Familial chylomicronemia) (Option C) involves markedly elevated triglyceride levels, often exceeding 1000 mg/dL, and is not associated with low HDL or orange tonsils.

Abetalipoproteinemia (Option D) is marked by low or absent ApoB-containing lipoproteins such as VLDL, LDL, and chylomicrons, and presents with fat malabsorption, acanthocytosis, and neurological symptoms, but not orange-colored tonsils.

questions.text: A 36-week pregnant woman is diagnosed with preeclampsia and started on magnesium sulfate therapy. According to the Pritchard regimen, what is the total loading dose of magnesium sulfate administered initially?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. 14 grams

Explanation:

Pritchard regimen is a widely used protocol for magnesium sulfate administration in eclampsia prophylaxis or treatment.

Pritchard regimen:

Step

Dose

Route

Timing

Loading

4 g

IV

Over 5 min

Loading

10 g (5 g each buttock)

IM

Immediately after IV

Maintenance

5 g

IM

Every 4 hrs in alternate buttocks

Duration

—

—

24 hrs post last seizure/delivery
  • Toxicity signs: Loss of patellar reflex, respiratory depression, oliguria (<25 mL/hr).
  • Antidote: 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate IV.

Preeclampsia: Pregnancy-specific hypertension after 20 weeks with proteinuria or signs of organ dysfunction. Caused by abnormal placentation → endothelial dysfunction.

Eclampsia: Preeclampsia + new-onset generalized tonic–clonic seizures not attributable to other causes.

Use of MgSO₄:

  • Seizure prophylaxis & treatment in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia (drug of choice).
  • Neuroprotection in imminent preterm delivery (<32 weeks) to reduce risk of cerebral palsy.
  • Tocolysis (dose dependent- not used).

Zuspan Regimen (IV regimen for eclampsia)

  • Loading dose: 4 g MgSO₄ IV given slowly over 5–10 minutes.
  • Maintenance dose: 1 g/hour IV infusion for 24 hours after last seizure or delivery.

4 grams (Option A): Only represents the IV loading part, not the full initial loading dose.

5 grams (Option D): Incorrect as 5 g IM is the maintenance dose, not the loading dose.

questions.text: A 22-year-old tall male presents with long limbs, increased arm span, hypermobile joints, and a high-arched palate. On examination, he has lens subluxation and a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic root dilation. Which of the following genes is most likely mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrillin-1 (FBN1)

Explanation:

  • The combination of tall stature, long limbs, increased arm span, hypermobile joints, high-arched palate, lens subluxation, and aortic root dilation strongly suggests Marfan Syndrome, a connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the Fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene affecting the cardiovascular, ocular, and skeletal systems.

Marfan Disease

The most common Clinical Manifestation is Skeletal Abnormalities.
  • Mitral Valve Prolapse (Most common Cardiac abnormality)
  • Aortic Dissection (Most common cause of death)
  • Retinal Detachment (eye problem)
  • Freely moveable Joint (most common Thumb joint)
  • Arachnodactyly (long fingers, spider fingers), High Arched Palate
  • Nine Feet Tall, Pigeon chest (defect in sternum)
  • Dislocation of the lens (Ectopia Lentis- Direction of dislocation is Supero Temporal)

Steinberg Sign: Positive if the thumb tip extends beyond the palm when folded into a closed fist.

Walker Sign: Positive if the thumb and fifth finger overlap when you grip your wrist with the opposite hand.

 

Incorrect Options:

COL4A5 (Option B) is associated with Alport syndrome (kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities).

COL1A1 (Option C) is linked to osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bones).

Elastin (Option D) mutations cause supravalvular aortic stenosis, not typical Marfan features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with pain in multiple bones and a history of increased hat size. On examination, some bones feel warm to touch. Biochemical investigations show normal serum calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, but markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paget’s disease of bone

Explanation:

In this patient, bone pain, increased hat size, warmth over bones, and isolated elevated ALP with normal calcium and phosphate are classic features of Paget’s disease of bone, indicating increased bone turnover and disorganized remodeling.

  • Paget’s disease of bone is a disorder of excessive bone remodeling with increased osteoclastic resorption followed by disorganized osteoblastic bone formation.
  • Common features:
    • Bone pain and deformities.
    • Increased hat size from skull thickening.
    • Warmth over affected bones due to increased vascularity.
  • Lab pattern:
    • Markedly elevated bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (BSAP) — reflects high osteoblastic activity.
    • Normal serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH (unless there is immobilization or fracture).
    • Urinary markers of bone resorption: hydroxyproline, deoxypyridinoline, C- and N-telopeptides, TRAP, cathepsin K.
    • Possible hyperuricemia due to increased bone turnover.

Osteosarcoma (Option B): Presents with localized bone pain, swelling, and destructive lytic–sclerotic lesions on imaging; ALP may be elevated but not as markedly as in Paget’s unless there is associated fracture or tumor activity. No diffuse bone involvement or hat size increase.

Multiple myeloma (Option C): Typically shows lytic bone lesions with hypercalcemia, anemia, and renal dysfunction. ALP is usually normal or only mildly elevated because osteoblastic activity is low.

Osteomalacia (Option D): Due to defective bone mineralization from vitamin D deficiency; labs show low calcium, low phosphate, elevated ALP, and increased PTH — not the normal calcium/phosphate seen here.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with chronic back pain that is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity. He also has a history of anterior uveitis. A lumbar spine X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation for early diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. MRI sacroiliac joints

Explanation:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy strongly associated with HLA-B27.
  • Early symptoms: Inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness, improvement with exercise, extra-articular features like anterior uveitis.
  • Radiological hallmark: Sacroiliitis — subchondral erosions, sclerosis, and eventual ankylosis
    • Initially, Subchondral Erosions develop at the lliac side of the Sacro-iliac Joints followed by Sclerosis & Proliferation
  • In early disease, plain X-rays may be normal because changes take years to appear.
  • MRI sacroiliac joints can detect bone marrow edema, synovitis, and erosions before they are visible on X-ray, enabling early diagnosis and treatment.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radioloxical Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 

  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

CT spine (Option A): CT is excellent for detecting bony detail and erosions, but it cannot detect active inflammation in early AS; changes may still be absent in the spine before sacroiliac involvement.

X-ray thoracolumbar spine (Option C): In early AS, spinal radiographs may be completely normal; sacroiliac joint involvement usually precedes spinal changes.

Bone scan (Option D): Bone scintigraphy can show increased uptake in inflamed areas, but it lacks the specificity and detailed anatomy provided by MRI, and it’s not the first-line choice for early AS detection.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to measure the degree of objective and target achievement, and assess the quality of results obtained in a health program?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Evaluation:

Explanation:

  • Evaluation systematically assesses the design, implementation, and outcomes of a program to determine effectiveness and inform decisions.
  • It focuses on measuring achievements versus objectives.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Planning involves program design.

Option B: Surveillance is ongoing data collection.

Option C: Monitoring is continuous tracking of activities but less comprehensive than evaluation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with chronic lower abdominal pain and dysmenorrhea. MRI is as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adenomyosis

Explanation: The diagnosis is adenomyosis because the MRI finding of increased junctional zone thickness is a classic feature.

  • Adenomyosis occurs when endometrial glands and stroma are present within the myometrium, causing uterine enlargement, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia.
  • MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting this, and thickening of the junctional zone is more suggestive of adenomyosis than other pathologies.

Uterine fibroid (Option A): Appears on MRI as a well-circumscribed, hypointense mass within the myometrium..

Endometriosis (Option C): Refers to endometrial tissue outside the uterus (ovaries, peritoneum); MRI findings differ and do not show junctional zone thickening.

Endometrial carcinoma (Option D): Presents as an endometrial mass or irregular endometrial thickening.

questions.text: A patient presents with irregular swelling over the foot, multiple discharging sinuses, and black granules. A KOH mount is performed on the discharge. What is the most likely observation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Slender dematiaceous fungi

Explanation:

  • Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, often involving the foot (Madura foot).
  • Black granules suggest eumycetoma caused by dematiaceous fungi (e.g., Madurella mycetomatis).
  • On KOH mount, eumycetoma shows slender, pigmented (dematiaceous) septate hyphae within granules.
  • Color of granules can help differentiate:
    • Black granules → eumycetoma (fungal)
    • White/yellow granules → actinomycetoma (bacterial)

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (fungal)
    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial)

 

 

 

 

Clinical Presentation

  • Initial Lesion:
    • Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years
  • Progression:
    • Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains
  • Complications:
    • Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage

Microscopic Examination

Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, (Option C) Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

 

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

Diagnostic Techniques

  • Biopsy and Culture:
    • Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens.
    • Culturing exudates for specific organism identification.
    • Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases.

Treatment

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

Arthrospores (Option A): Seen in dermatophyte infections such as Trichophyton or Microsporum; not characteristic of mycetoma.
 

Yeast (Option C): Round/oval budding forms typical of Candida or Cryptococcus; not seen in eumycetoma granules.
 

Septate hyphae 4-5 µm (Option D): While eumycetoma fungi have septate hyphae, the distinctive finding here is that they are slender and dematiaceous (pigmented), not just septate hyphae of generic width.

questions.text: A 32-year old woman presents with recurrent episodes of palpitations and is diagnosed with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for long term prophylais of PSVT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Oral verapamil

Explanation:

  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is often due to AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT). It presents with sudden-onset, regular, narrow-complex tachycardia.

  • Acute termination: target AV nodal conduction.

  • Aim is to rapidly break the reentrant circuit

  • Drug - IV adenosine (first choice), IV verapamil/diltiazem, IV β-blockers

Prophylaxis (prevent recurrence):

  • Aim is to suppress AV nodal conduction chronically.

  • Drugs used - Oral verapamil/diltiazem, β-blockers, sometimes flecainide or propafenone in select cases

Oral verapamil:

  • Class: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker.

  • Mechanism: Blocks L-type Ca²⁺ channels in AV node → prolongs conduction time, increases refractory period.

  • Use: Chronic prophylaxis in AVNRT/AVRT when ablation isn’t done or not preferred.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV adenosine: Very short half-life (~10 s); only for acute termination, not long-term prophylaxis.

Option B - IV esmolol: Short-acting β-blocker, used acutely in some tachyarrhythmias but not for chronic prevention.

Option C - Oral phenytoin: Anti-epileptic with limited antiarrhythmic role (historically in digoxin toxicity–induced ventricular arrhythmias); not used for PSVT prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 30 year old female was brought to EMR after fire on examination of lower limb full-thickness burns and deep partial-thickness burns were present involving it Circumferentially, procedure was performed as given below, identify the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Escharotomy

Explanation: The appropriatet answer is escharotomy because circumferential full-thickness burns produce a tough, leathery, non-elastic eschar. This can restrict circulation and ventilation (if on chest) due to swelling beneath the eschar.

  • Escharotomy is an emergency procedure where the eschar is incised longitudinally to relieve pressure, restore distal circulation, and prevent compartment syndrome.
  • It is performed along the medial and lateral aspects of the limb, avoiding neurovascular bundles.

Debridement (Option B): Removal of necrotic tissue, usually done during wound care, not the immediate emergency procedure for circumferential burns with vascular compromise.

Excised to healthy tissue fat/fascia (Option C): Refers to tangential or fascial excision in burn surgery, typically performed in planned operative settings, not as an emergency decompression.

Early skin grafting (Option D): Performed after excision of burn tissue to cover wounds and promote healing; not indicated as the first step in this emergency.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from an endemic region presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb. A peripheral blood smear shows the following structure. What is the most likely cause of his limb swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lymphatic obstruction

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation and peripheral smear findings (likely Wuchereria bancrofti microfilariae) are classic for lymphatic filariasis.
  • Adult worms lodge in and damage lymphatic vessels, causing chronic lymphatic obstruction and progressive lymphedema that can advance to elephantiasis.
  • This swelling is typically localized (often in a limb or scrotum) and non-pitting in later stages due to fibrosis.

Hypoalbuminemia (Option A): Causes generalized pitting edema (e.g., in nephrotic syndrome, liver disease) via reduced plasma oncotic pressure; not localized swelling.

Hypoproteinemia (Option C): Similar to hypoalbuminemia — produces diffuse edema, not isolated limb involvement.

Increased hydrostatic pressure (Option D): Seen in conditions like congestive heart failure or chronic venous insufficiency; usually bilateral and symmetrical, not the marked unilateral swelling typical of filariasis.

questions.text: Amiodarone primarily acts during which phase of the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phase 3:

Explanation:

Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug (Vaughan-Williams classification) whose primary mechanism is blocking potassium channels.

  • In ventricular action potential, Phase 3 is the repolarization phase, driven mainly by outward K⁺ efflux.

  • By inhibiting these potassium channels, amiodarone prolongs repolarization → increases the action potential duration (APD) and the effective refractory period (ERP).

Multi-class effects: Though Class III, it also blocks Na⁺ channels (Class I), β-receptors (Class II), and Ca²⁺ channels (Class IV).
Side effects: Pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction (contains iodine), liver toxicity, corneal deposits, skin discoloration (“blue man”).

ECG effect: Prolongs QT interval without significant torsades risk (unlike many other Class III drugs).

Action potential phases (ventricular myocyte):

 

Phases

Event

Major ions

Drugs acting

0

Rapid depolarization

Na⁺ influx

Class I (Na⁺ channel blockers)

1

Initial repolarization

Transient K⁺ efflux

-

2

Plateau

Ca²⁺ influx (L-type) balanced by K⁺ efflux

Class IV (CCBs), some Class II (β-blockers)

3

Repolarization

K⁺ efflux

Class III (amiodarone, sotalol)

4

Resting potential

Na⁺/K⁺ pump, leak channels

-

questions.text: An HIV-positive mother with a viral load of 1200 copies/mL delivers a baby. What is the most appropriate antiretroviral prophylaxis for the newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 weeks

  • In this case, the maternal viral load is 1200 copies/mL, hence, the infant is considered high risk, and since the mother’s treatment is not known, dual prophylaxis with Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 weeks is aimed at covering both intrapartum and early postpartum exposure.
  • Nevirapine (NVP) — NNRTI that inhibits reverse transcriptase, preventing viral replication soon after exposure.
  • Zidovudine (AZT) — NRTI that interferes with viral DNA synthesis, offering a complementary mechanism.
  • The dual regimen is more effective than single-drug prophylaxis in reducing perinatal HIV transmission in babies born to mothers with detectable viremia.
  • Early infant diagnosis with HIV DNA PCR at 6 weeks is mandatory.

Nevirapine for 6 weeks (Option A): Reserved for truly low-risk infants (maternal viral load <50 copies/mL close to delivery).

Nevirapine for 12 weeks (Option C): Used for high-risk breastfed infants when the mother is not virally suppressed.

Zidovudine for 4 weeks (Option D): Older protocol, no longer preferred in detectable maternal viral load scenarios per updated Indian recommendations.

questions.text: A patient presents with frothy sputum , dyspnea and PND and died. On autopsy lung HPE shows hemosiderin laden macrophages. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) RV failure

Explanation: The appropriate answer is RV failure because the findings point to isolated chronic left-sided heart failure with pulmonary congestion, not biventricular failure.

  • Chronic left heart failure leads to increased pulmonary venous pressure → pulmonary edema → leakage of RBCs into alveoli → breakdown into hemosiderin-laden macrophages (“heart failure cells”).
  • While RV failure can eventually develop secondary to pulmonary hypertension (cor pulmonale), in early or purely left-sided disease it may be absent — making it the least likely feature here.

Volume overload (Option A): Common in HF due to RAAS activation and sodium/water retention.

Pulmonary vein obstruction (Option C): Functionally occurs from elevated left atrial pressure due to mitral valve disease or LV dysfunction.

Protein-losing enteropathy (Option D): Rare in HF but can occur in chronic congestive states; more common in right HF or constrictive pericarditis but still possible with severe chronic congestion.

questions.text: A patient is on salbutamol and ipratropium but continues to have nocturnal exacerbations of asthma. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - LABA plus inhalation steroids

Explanation:

1. Stepwise asthma management (GINA guidelines)

Asthma treatment follows a step-up approach based on symptom control.

For an adult with persistent symptoms despite SABA + LAMA:

  • If the patient is already on SABA (salbutamol) and LAMA (ipratropium) but still has nocturnal symptoms, this indicates uncontrolled asthma.

  • The next controller step is to add an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) combined with a long-acting β₂-agonist (LABA).

2. ICS + LABA:

  • ICS: Reduces airway inflammation (core pathology in asthma).

  • LABA: Provides long-acting bronchodilation, particularly useful for nocturnal symptoms (e.g., salmeterol, formoterol).

  • Combination addresses both the inflammatory and bronchospasm components.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral corticosteroids: Reserved for acute severe exacerbations or very severe, uncontrolled asthma after inhaled therapy has been optimized; not the next immediate step here.

Option C - Montelukast: Leukotriene receptor antagonist; useful for allergic or exercise-induced asthma, but less effective than ICS + LABA for uncontrolled persistent asthma.

Option D - Increase salbutamol dose: SABA overuse does not control inflammation, can cause tolerance and side effects (tachycardia, hypokalemia).

questions.text: A child presents to casualty in an unresponsive state after consuming peanuts. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Chest compressions

Explanation:

The child is unresponsive after choking, which indicates a complete airway obstruction and ineffective breathing.

According to pediatric basic life support (BLS) guidelines:

  • If unresponsive → Start CPR immediately with chest compressions, even before attempting to ventilate.
  • Compressions can help generate intrathoracic pressure to dislodge the foreign body.
  • Between compressions, open the airway and look for an object — remove only if visible.

Abdominal thrusts (Heimlich) are for responsive children >1 year. In unresponsive patients, chest compressions are preferred to avoid delays and provide circulatory support.

Abdominal thrusts (Option A): Only for responsive children >1 year. Not done in unresponsive cases.

Back slaps (Option B): Used in infants (<1 year) who are responsive with choking. Not for unresponsive cases.

Endotracheal intubation (Option D): Not first-line; obstruction must be relieved first. Attempting intubation before clearing the airway is ineffective and wastes precious time.

questions.text: A lady has come at 36 weeks with reduced fetal movement NST shows one acceleration in 20 min. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Continue NST for upto 40 min

Explanation: The correct answer is continue NST for upto 40 min because the non-stress test (NST) is considered reactive when there are ≥2 accelerations in 20 minutes.

  • The presence of one acceleration without decelerations in 20 minutes is an equivocal/indeterminate result, so the test should be extended to 40 minutes before deciding further action.
  • This allows time for fetal sleep–wake cycles to change, as lack of movement may simply indicate a fetal sleep phase.

Non stress test:

  • The NST is a non-invasive, quick, and reliable method to assess fetal heart rate response to fetal movements, which is crucial given the reported decrease in fetal movements.
  • During an NST, the mother is placed in a comfortable position, and external monitors are attached to her abdomen to record the fetal heart rate and any fetal movements for 20 minutes.
  • A reactive NST (presence of accelerations in fetal heart rate with movements) indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive NST (lack of sufficient accelerations) may necessitate further testing or intervention.
  • A CTG tracing is classified as reactive when it exhibits at least two accelerations of the fetal heart rate, each lasting at least 15 seconds and exceeding 15 beats per minute above the baseline, within a 20-minute period.

Wait and watch (Option A): Simply waiting without completing the 40-minute NST may miss evolving fetal compromise.

Immediate cesarean section (Option B): Indicated for persistent abnormal patterns with evidence of acute distress.

Induce labor (Option D) is not appropriate at this stage because the NST is only borderline non-reactive, and further monitoring is needed before deciding on delivery.

questions.text: A cut section of liver is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Focal nodular hyperplasia

Explanation:

A well-demarcated liver lesion with a central stellate scar on gross examination is characteristic of Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH).

  • It is a benign, non-neoplastic lesion that is most common in women. It occurs due to altered blood flow, which causes hyperplastic changes in hepatocytes.
  • Multifocal FNH can occur in
    • Hepatic or extrahepatic hemangioma
    • Vascular malformations
    • Brain tumours (meningioma, astrocytoma)
    • Histopathology
      • It is less than 5 cm in diameter, well-circumscribed, lacks a capsule, and has a central stellate scar.
      • Microscopically, fibrous septa radiating from the central scar divide the hepatic parenchyma into nodules. A large central artery is usually present.

The image shows fibrous septae dividing the parenchyma.

  • USG: It is incidentally seen on imaging.

 

A USG of the liver indicating a mass with a central stellate scar

Incorrect Options:

Hepatic adenoma (Option A): Usually solitary, lacks central scar, associated with oral contraceptives.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option B): Malignant tumor; often shows hemorrhage, necrosis, no central scar.

Hemangioma (Option D): Cavernous vascular lesion, red-blue on cut section, no central scar.

questions.text: What is true about the investigation shown below?

choices.text: Non invasive procedure to diagnose PUJ obstruction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non invasive procedure to diagnose PUJ obstruction

Explanation: The image depicts Intravenous Urography (IVU), also called Intravenous Pyelography (IVP).

  • It is a non-invasive imaging technique where IV contrast is injected and serial X-rays are taken to outline the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • It is particularly useful to evaluate anatomy and pathology at the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ), ureter, and collecting system.

Invasive procedure (Option A): IVU is not considered invasive; only involves IV contrast administration.

Gold standard for bladder cancer (Option C): The gold standard for bladder cancer diagnosis is cystoscopy with biopsy, not IVU.

Done percutaneously (Option D): That describes Percutaneous Nephrostography, not IVU.

questions.text: A man reports that he is receiving orders from God to follow white birds in a specific direction. What is the most appropriate description of this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Delusional perception

Explanation:

  • Delusional perception occurs when a real, normal perception is given a false, fixed, and idiosyncratic meaning that is not culturally or logically justified.
  • It is a primary delusion, meaning it arises suddenly without preceding mental illness symptoms or logical explanation.
  • In this case, seeing white birds is real, but interpreting them as divine orders to follow is delusional perception.
  • Often seen in schizophrenia and other primary psychotic disorders.

Visual hallucination (Option B): Involves seeing things that are not present in reality; here the bird exists, but its meaning is delusional.

Thought insertion (Option C): Belief that external forces are putting thoughts into one’s mind, not misinterpretation of a real object.

Passivity phenomenon (Option D): Belief that one’s own actions, feelings, or impulses are being controlled by an outside force, not simply assigning false meaning to perception.

questions.text: A woman presents with features suggestive of uterine prolapse, as seen in the given image. Based on the likely anatomical defect, which of the following structures is primarily responsible for the support that is compromised?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cardinal (Mackenrodt's) ligament

 

Explanation: The correct answer is cardinal ligament because it, along with the uterosacral ligament, provides primary (mechanical) support to the uterus by anchoring the cervix to the lateral pelvic wall. In uterine prolapse, this primary support is weakened or disrupted.

  • Primary support: Cardinal ligaments + uterosacral ligaments
  • Secondary support: Pelvic diaphragm, urogenital diaphragm, perineal body
  • Tertiary support: Peritoneal folds and ligaments like the broad ligament

Uterine Ligaments

Ligament

Function

Associated disease

Broad Ligament

(Option B)
  • Double layers of peritoneum extend from the lateral walls of the uterus to the pelvic walls.
  • Contain the fallopian tube, ovarian ligament, and round ligament.
  • Broad ligament cysts
  • Endometriosis

Round Ligament

(Option A)
  • Extends from the uterine cornu through the inguinal canal to the labia majora. (do not significantly contribute to uterine support)
  • Round ligament varicosities
  • Pain during pregnancy due to stretching.

Uterosacral Ligament

  • Help to support the uterus, prevent it from being forced down by intra-abdominal pressure
  • Antevert the uterus by pulling the cervix back.
  • Contain sympathetic & parasympathetic nerves.
  • Uterosacral ligament endometriosis.
  • Retroverted/ tilted back when weakened.

Mackenrodt's Ligaments
  • AKA transverse cervical ligaments or cardinal ligaments.
  • Consist of vessels and connective tissue.
  • Parametritis

Ovarian Ligament

  • Connects the ovary to the uterus.
  • Stabilizes the position of the ovary.
  • Ovarian torsion.
  • Ovarian cysts or tumors

Suspensory Ligament of the Ovary
  • Extends from the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall.
  • Contains the ovarian vessels and nerves.
  • Ovarian vein syndrome

Sacrospinous ligament (Option D): Used surgically for vault suspension post-hysterectomy; not the primary support of an intact uterus.

questions.text: Patient presents with dry cough, dyspnea and stridor since 1 month. HPE of hilar LN shows stellate granulomas with giant cells and circular lamellated concretions on histopathology. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sarcoidosis

Explanation: The presence of stellate granulomas with giant cells and lamellated concretions (Schaumann bodies) in hilar lymph nodes is characteristic of sarcoidosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, often involving the lungs and intrathoracic lymph nodes.
    • Non-caseating granulomas, giant cells, asteroid bodies, and Schaumann bodies are typical histopathological findings.
    • The patient’s respiratory symptoms, stridor, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy support this diagnosis.

Asteroid Bodies:

  • Asteroid bodies are stellate or star-shaped structures seen within the cytoplasm of giant cells.
  • They are composed of aggregated proteinaceous material consisting primarily of fibrin.

Schaumann Bodies:

  • They are concentrically laminated, basophilic structures found within the cytoplasm of giant cells.
  • They comprise calcium and proteinaceous material, such as mucopolysaccharides and immunoglobulins.

Schaumann bodies Schaumann bodies- magnified

Tuberculosis (Option B): Shows caseating granulomas with central necrosis, not the non-caseating granulomas with Schaumann bodies seen in sarcoidosis.

GPA (Option C): Characterized by necrotizing granulomas and vasculitis affecting the upper/lower respiratory tract and kidneys; histology does not show lamellated concretions.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): Features loosely formed interstitial granulomas without Schaumann bodies; usually history of antigen exposure (e.g., mold, bird droppings).

questions.text: A 25 year patient had a Road traffic accident was initially conscious but later became unconscious and subsequently died. On postmortem examination, multiple petechial haemorrhages are seen in the corpus callosum, what is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation: The scenario depicts diffuse axonal injury (DAI), which is a severe form of traumatic brain injury caused by shearing forces during rapid acceleration–deceleration (as in high-speed RTA).

  • Pathology: Axonal disruption at the gray–white junction, corpus callosum, and brainstem.
  • Postmortem finding: Multiple petechial hemorrhages in these areas.
  • Clinical course: Often the patient becomes unconscious immediately or shortly after injury and remains comatose; some may have a brief lucid period. Mortality is high.
  • DAI hallmark: Microscopic or small petechial hemorrhages at the gray–white junction and corpus callosum.
  • Poor prognosis; often diagnosed by MRI (CT may be normal).

Epidural hematoma (EDH) (Option A): Classically due to middle meningeal artery rupture; features a lucid interval, biconvex hyperdensity on CT, localized, not petechial hemorrhages in corpus callosum.

Subdural hematoma (SDH) (Option C): Due to bridging vein rupture; appears crescent-shaped on CT; not characterized by multiple petechial hemorrhages in deep white matter.

SAH (Option D): Presents with thunderclap headache; due to aneurysmal rupture or trauma, but hemorrhage is in subarachnoid space, not localized petechiae in corpus callosum.

questions.text: A subject reaches high altitude suddenly. Few days later, he was diagnosed as having cerebral edema. Identify the correct mechanism behind this pathophysiology.

choices.text: Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasodilation
High arterial pH induced cerebral vasodilation
Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasoconstriction
High arterial pH induced cerebral vasoconstriction

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low arterial PO2 induced cerebral vasodilation

Explanation:

  • At high altitude, the drop in arterial PO₂ causes hypoxemia, prompting cerebral vasodilation to enhance oxygen delivery, but this response increases capillary pressure and permeability, leading to fluid leakage and resulting in cerebral edema.

High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE)

Category

Details

Cause

Capillary leakage leads to brain swelling, often due to rapid ascent to high altitudes.

Symptoms

Severe headache, nausea, vomiting, ataxia (lack of coordination), disorientation, confusion, hallucinations, papilledema, and potentially coma due to herniation of the brain through tentorium.

Mechanism
  • Increased capillary pressure is caused by hypoxia-induced local vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels, leading to fluid leakage into brain tissues. (Option A)
  • Chemical factors like vascular endothelial growth factor and inflammatory cytokines may also increase endothelial permeability.

Onset

Typically within 8-24 hours after rapid ascent to high altitude; symptoms can progress quickly over the next 4-8 days if untreated.

Treatment
  • First Step - Immediate descent to a lower altitude
  • Administration of oxygen
  • High-dose dexamethasone to reduce cerebral edema and inflammation
  • Acetazolamide to promote acclimatization and reduce CSF formation.
  • Portable Hyperbaric Chamber: Symptoms will return when the patient leaves the chamber, but they may improve briefly, allowing the patient to help with evacuation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High arterial pH induced cerebral vasodilation: At high altitude, hyperventilation causes respiratory alkalosis (↑pH), which actually causes vasoconstriction, not vasodilation.

Option C - Low arterial PO₂ induced cerebral vasoconstriction: This is incorrect; low PO₂ causes vasodilation in the brain.

Option D - High arterial pH induced cerebral vasoconstriction: While true, this is not the primary mechanism for cerebral edema in high altitude. The edema is due to hypoxia-induced vasodilation, not alkalosis-induced vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles and heavy vaginal bleeding for several months. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observe and reassess after a few months

questions.solution:
Answer: D. Perform an endometrial biopsy

Explanation:

In a perimenopausal woman (>45 years) with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), the major concern is endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Endometrial biopsy is the first-line diagnostic step to rule out malignancy, especially when:

  • Endometrial thickness >4 mm in postmenopausal
  • Persistent AUB in perimenopausal
  • Risk factors: obesity, unopposed estrogen, diabetes, family history of endometrial cancer
  • Here, the woman is 46 years old (perimenopausal) with heavy bleeding and endometrial thickness of 16 mm → biopsy is warranted before starting any treatment.

Situation

Endometrial Thickness

Prepubertal

< 5 mm

Reproductive age – Menstrual phase (Day 1–4)

1–4 mm

Early proliferative phase (Day 5–9)

4–8 mm

Late proliferative / Pre-ovulatory (Day 10–14)

6–10 mm

Secretory phase (Day 15–28)

7–14 mm

Postmenopausal (on HRT)

≤ 8 mm

Postmenopausal (no HRT)

≤ 4 mm (≥ 5 mm suspicious for malignancy)

Hysterectomy (Option A): Definitive treatment but not the first step without a histological diagnosis. Only done if malignancy or severe atypical hyperplasia is confirmed and fertility is not desired.

Start combined oral contraceptive pills (Option B): May control bleeding in benign cases but starting without ruling out malignancy is unsafe. Hormones can mask symptoms and delay diagnosis.

Observe and reassess after a few months (Option C): Delays diagnosis of possible cancer. In high-risk age group with abnormal bleeding, observation is not acceptable.

questions.text: A farmer presents with an ulcerative skin lesion showing signs of necrosis. Smear from the ulcer stained with polychrome methylene blue reveals capsulated bacilli that are McFadyean reaction positive. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bacillus anthracis

Explanation:

  • Bacillus anthracis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming rod with a polypeptide capsule made of poly-D-glutamic acid.
  • In McFadyean reaction, the capsule stains purple-pink against a blue background using polychrome methylene blue, which is diagnostic.
  • Cutaneous anthrax typically presents with a painless black eschar surrounded by marked edema (“malignant pustule”) after contact with infected animals or contaminated animal products — common in farmers.

Clostridium perfringens (Option A) causes gas gangrene and does not show a capsule or McFadyean positivity.

Yersinia pestis (Option C) causes plague with bipolar staining and does not test positive for McFadyean reaction .

Francisella tularensis (Option D) causes tularemia but is not identified via McFadyean stain

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman with a history of preeclampsia undergoes a cesarean section at term. Her BMI is 37. She is currently stable in the postnatal ward.Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylaxis to prevent DVT for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) LMWH

Explanation: The correct answer is low molecular weight heparin.

This patient has multiple postpartum VTE risk factors:

  • Cesarean delivery (surgical risk)
  • Obesity (BMI ≥30)
  • Hypertensive disorder of pregnancy (preeclampsia)

According to RCOG, women with ≥2 persisting risk factors should receive LMWH prophylaxis for at least 10 days postpartum. LMWH is preferred because it

  • Has proven efficacy in preventing DVT and PE in postpartum women
  • Does not cross into breast milk
  • Has predictable pharmacokinetics and easy once-daily dosing for prophylaxis

Warfarin (Option A): While safe in breastfeeding, it is not used for initial postpartum VTE prophylaxis unless there’s another indication (e.g., mechanical heart valve).

Clopidogrel (Option B): Antiplatelet agent used for arterial thrombosis prevention, not venous thrombosis prophylaxis in postpartum women.

Aspirin (Option C): Used during pregnancy to reduce preeclampsia risk; not effective for postpartum DVT prevention.

questions.text: A patient has elevated phenylalanine levels (40 mg/dL), but phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme levels are normal. Which cofactor deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Explanation:

The elevated phenylalanine levels despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase indicate a deficiency of its cofactor, Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH₄), which renders the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) nonfunctional and leads to hyperphenylalaninemia.

Phenylalanine has 2 metabolic fates in the body

Major

  • Phenylalanine gets converted into tyrosine with the help of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in Phenylketonuria.
  • Requires tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) as a cofactor (Option B)

Minor

Phenylalanine gets converted into Phenylpyruvate by transamination.

Phenylpyruvate can further undergo different pathways:

  • Phenylpyruvate can get reduced to phenyl lactate
  • Phenylpyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form phenylacetate
  • Phenylacetate combines with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is excreted in urine.

Incorrect Options:

Tetrahydrofolate (Option A) is used in 1-carbon transfers, particularly in nucleotide and amino acid metabolism — not involved in phenylalanine metabolism.

Thiamine (Option C) is a cofactor for enzymes like pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, not related to phenylalanine.

Pyridoxine (Option D) is a cofactor for transamination reactions and neurotransmitter synthesis — not involved in the PAH reaction.

questions.text: Binocular single vision consists of the following components:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. a. SMP b. Fusion

  • The first image shows two dissimilar pictures meant to be seen simultaneously (e.g., dog and its kennel parts) — this is a test of Simultaneous Macular Perception (SMP).
  • The second image shows two complementary/similar pictures intended to be merged into one percept (one image completes the other) — that is a test for Fusion.

Binocular single vision:

  • SMP (Simultaneous Macular Perception): the baseline ability to perceive two images (one from each fovea) at the same time; absence suggests suppression.
  • Fusion: the cortex’s process of aligning and merging the two similar images into one percept — requires both motor alignment and sensory correspondence.
  • Functional relationship: SMP permits inputs; fusion integrates them; without SMP fusion is hard to establish.
  • Clinical tests: SMP and fusion are tested with synoptophore slides and Worth’s four-dot before testing stereopsis (Titmus/Randot).
     

Grade

Name

Description

Grade 1

SMP

Perception of two dissimilar images simultaneously

Grade 2

Fusion

Merging of two similar images into one

Grade 3

Stereopsis

Depth perception from binocular vision

a. Stereopsis b. Fusion (Option B) is incorrect because the first image is not a stereopsis (depth) test. Stereopsis tests use binocular disparity/random-dot or contour-based depth targets, not two dissimilar objects; you can’t get depth from that first slide.

a. Fusion b. SMP (Option C) - Wrong mapping: the first image is not designed for fusion (it shows dissimilar items), and the second is clearly intended for merging — so the pair is reversed.

a. SMP b. Stereopsis (Option D) is incorrect because the second image is not a stereopsis/depth stimulus; it’s a fusion stimulus. Stereopsis requires disparity-based targets (Titmus/Randot), not complementary pictorial halves.

questions.text: A frameshift mutation occurs due to the insertion of a new nucleotide at the 4th position of an mRNA sequence with 900 nucleotides. What is the most likely outcome of this mutation?

choices.text: No change in the final protein
No change due to RNA editing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Complete change in protein production

Explanation:

The insertion of a nucleotide at the 4th position of a 900-nucleotide mRNA sequence causes Frameshift Mutation, most likely resulting in a complete alteration of the protein produced.

  • It occur when nucleotides are inserted into or deleted from the DNA or mRNA sequence, causing a shift in the reading frame of the genetic code.
  • This usually results in:
    • A completely different sequence of amino acids from the mutation site onward.
    • Potential introduction of premature stop codons, leading to truncated proteins.
    • Loss of the original protein function.

Incorrect Options:

No change in the final protein (Option A): Unlikely, because an insertion at position 4 shifts the reading frame early, changing most of the protein.

Partial protein production (Option B): Possible if a premature stop codon is introduced, but the question emphasizes the insertion at the 4th position, so the frame shift affects nearly the entire protein.

No change due to RNA editing (Option D): RNA editing is rare and usually doesn't correct frameshift mutations, so unlikely.

questions.text: What is the Zasko phenomenon?

choices.text: Seepage of blood from wounds around time of death
Gaping of wound along tension lines

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tendon reflex occurring after death:

Explanation:

  • The Zasko phenomenon refers to the persistence of certain tendon reflexes for a short period after death.
  • It occurs due to residual neuromuscular excitability before complete cessation of neuronal activity and before rigor mortis sets in.
  • These reflexes can occasionally be elicited by tapping tendons soon after death and may be used in early postmortem examinations to help estimate the time since death.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Seepage of blood from wounds is a perimortem finding but is not the Zasko phenomenon.

Option C - Clotting of blood after death is a normal postmortem change, not related to reflexes.

Option D - Gaping of wounds along tension lines is due to skin elasticity and is unrelated to postmortem reflex activity.

questions.text: By what primary mechanism does hydrochlorothiazide help prevent the formation of calcium stones?

choices.text: It increases the urinary excretion of citrate, which acts as a chelating agent.
It increases calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to a decrease in urinary calcium excretion.
It increases the filtration of calcium at the glomerulus, thereby reducing serum calcium levels.
It directly dissolves existing calcium stones by altering urinary pH and increasing their solubility.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It increases calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to a decrease in urinary calcium excretion.

Explanation:

Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) helps prevent the formation of calcium stones by enhancing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, thereby reducing calcium levels in the urine.

  • It is a thiazide diuretic.
  • Site: It acts at the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron.
  • MOA: Increased calcium reabsorption → Reduced calcium excretion in urine.
    • Lowers the risk of calcium stone formation (e.g., calcium oxalate stones), as less calcium is available in the urine to precipitate and form stones.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It increases the urinary excretion of citrate, which acts as a chelating agent: Thiazides do not increase citrate excretion. In fact, low citrate levels can promote stone formation, but this is not the mechanism by which HCTZ works.

Option C: It increases the filtration of calcium at the glomerulus, thereby reducing serum calcium levels - Thiazides do not affect calcium filtration at the glomerulus. Their primary action is post-filtration, at the distal tubule.

Option D: It directly dissolves existing calcium stones by altering urinary pH and increasing their solubility - Thiazides do not dissolve stones. They prevent formation by reducing urinary calcium.

questions.text: What is the correct nerve supply to the muscles labelled as A and B?

choices.text: A - Nerve to mylohyoid, B- Facial nerve
A - Facial nerve, B- Spinal accessory nerve
A- Facial nerve, B- Mandibular nerve
A - Spinal accessory nerve, B- Mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A- Facial nerve, B- Mandibular nerve

Explanation:

  • The labeled structures receive their nerve supply as follows:
  • A (Posterior belly of digastric): Facial nerve
  • B (Anterior belly of digastric): Mandibular nerve

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A - Nerve to mylohyoid, B- Facial nerve: This incorrectly swaps the nerves; the posterior belly is innervated by the facial nerve, not the nerve to mylohyoid.

Option B - A - Facial nerve, B- Spinal accessory nerve: The spinal accessory nerve does not supply the anterior belly of digastric but innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

Option D - A - Spinal accessory nerve, B- Mandibular nerve: The posterior belly is not supplied by the spinal accessory nerve but by the facial nerve.

questions.text:
Across a capillary, there is no fluid movement. Pressure values are given below.


	Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 18 mmHg
	Capillary oncotic pressure is 27 mmHg
	Interstitial fluid oncotic pressure is 7 mmHg


Calculate the interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - -2 mmHg:

Explanation:

  • The interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure in the given scenario is determined to be -2 mmHg.
  • As per Starling equation, which governs fluid movement across capillaries:

In the above ques:

Where:

  • Pc = Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 18 mmHg
  • Pi = Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure = ?
  • πc = Capillary oncotic pressure = 27 mmHg
  • πi = Interstitial oncotic pressure = 7 mmHg
     

Since no fluid movement is occurring, the net filtration pressure (NFP) is 0:

  • 0 = (18-Pi) - (27-7)
  • 0 = (18-Pi) - 20
  • 0 = -Pi - 2
  • Pi = -2 mmHg

This negative value reflects a slightly subatmospheric interstitial pressure, which helps pull fluid into capillaries and maintain balance.

questions.text: A neonate presents with seizures and is found to have a cherry red spot on fundus examination. Enzyme assay reveals deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Which of the following substances is most likely to be accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) GM2 ganglioside

Explanation:

  • A neonate presenting with seizures and a cherry red spot likely has Tay-Sachs Disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons.

Tay-Sachs Disease

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Cause

Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme

Accumulation

GM2 ganglioside in ganglion cells and neurons

Clinical Manifestations
  • Initial symptoms include loss of head control, inability to sit, exaggerated startle response to sound, and a disproportionately large head.
  • Progressive features include spasticity, deafness, and blindness.
  • Not associated with organomegaly.

Fundus Finding

Cherry-red spot is caused by GM2 ganglioside accumulation in the ganglion cells of the retina, creating a contrast with the normal red fovea.

Incorrect Options:

GM1 ganglioside (Option A): Accumulates in GM1 gangliosidosis, caused by β-galactosidase deficiency.

Sphingomyelin (Option C): Accumulates in Niemann-Pick disease, caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency.

Glucocerebroside (Option D): Accumulates in Gaucher disease, caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency.

questions.text: A surgeon by mistake injures one structure posterio to epiploic foramen. Which of the following structure is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inferior vena cava:

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is the IVC (Inferior Vena Cava), as it forms the posterior boundary of the Epiploic Foramen and is therefore the most likely structure to be injured from behind.

Epiploic Foramen / Omental Foramen / Foramen of Winslow

A vertical slit-like opening connecting the lesser sac with the greater sac, located behind the right free margin of the lesser omentum at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra.

Boundaries
  • Anterior: Right free margin of the lesser omentum (portal vein, proper hepatic artery, bile duct)
  • Posterior: Inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, T12 vertebra (Option C)
  • Superior: Caudate process of the liver
  • Inferior: First part of the duodenum, horizontal part of the hepatic artery

Clinical Relevance
  • Pringle Maneuver: A technique to control bleeding from the liver by compressing the free edge of the lesser omentum.
  • Fluid Collections: The apposed walls of the foramen can lead to isolated fluid collections in the greater sac or omental bursa.

 Incorrect Options:

Option A: Abdominal aorta lies posterior to the IVC and is not in direct relation to the epiploic foramen.

Option B: Hepatic artery is part of the anterior boundary within the portal triad.

Option D: Portal vein is part of the anterior boundary within the portal triad, not posterior.

questions.text: After a building collapse, a patient presents with airway obstruction and mouth filled with concrete debris. BP is 90/60 mmHg, HR 105/min. The given procedure is performed (image shown). Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is true?

choices.text: It provides adequate ventilation for up to 6 hours
It must be followed by a formal tracheostomy
It allows for removal of large foreign bodies from the airway
It can be safely used for prolonged airway management without further intervention

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It must be followed by a formal tracheostomy

Explanation: The image depicts a needle cricothyroidotomy, an emergency airway procedure used when endotracheal intubation is not possible due to severe upper airway obstruction

  • This technique provides temporary oxygenation via a large-bore needle inserted through the cricothyroid membrane, but it does not ensure adequate ventilation long-term due to high airway resistance.
  • Therefore, it must be converted to a definitive airway (formal surgical cricothyroidotomy or tracheostomy) as soon as possible, usually within 30–45 minutes.

It provides adequate ventilation for up to 6 hours (Option A): False - it’s only for short-term oxygenation (max ~30–45 minutes), not hours.

It allows for removal of large foreign bodies from the airway (Option C): False - it bypasses obstruction but cannot remove debris.

It can be safely used for prolonged airway management without further intervention (Option D): False - prolonged use risks CO₂ retention and inadequate ventilation.

questions.text: A child presents with visual disturbances and delayed growth. Imaging reveals a suprasellar mass, and histopathology shows the presence of "wet keratin" (compact, eosinophilic anucleate keratin). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

The above history of a child presenting with visual disturbances and delayed growth with imaging features of a suprasellar mass, and histopathology showing the presence of "wet keratin" is suggestive of Craniopharyngioma.

  • Rare, benign CNS tumour
  • Often partly cystic in nature
  • Occurs in the sellar/suprasellar region

Pathophysiology:

  • It can compress normal pituitary tissue and result in pituitary deficiencies, particularly of the anterior pituitary hormones.
  • It can also compress the optic chiasm and also present with hydrocephalus secondary to third ventricle compression.

Clinical Features:

  • Headaches: Due to increased intracranial pressure or meningeal irritation.
  • Visual Disturbances: Temporal hemianopsia is common due to optic chiasm compression.

Endocrine Deficiencies:

  • Growth hormone (GH) deficiency.
  • Gonadotroph, ACTH, TSH, and vasopressin deficiencies.

Other Symptoms: Hydrocephalus, nausea, vomiting, and possible cranial nerve palsies.

Microscopic Examination:

Adamantinomatous Craniopharyngioma (ACP):

  • More common in children.
  • Solid and cystic components.
  • Characterised by squamous epithelium, "wet keratin," and calcifications.

Papillary Craniopharyngioma (PCP):

  • More common in adults.
    • Predominantly solid, with well-differentiated squamous epithelium.
    • Calcifications are rare.

Imaging:

MRI: Preferred modality for detailed evaluation.

  • ACP: Heterogeneous with cystic areas and calcifications.
  • PCP: Solid and less commonly cystic or calcified.

CT: Best for identifying calcifications.

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Medulloblastoma (Option B):

  • Typical location: Midline cerebellum (vermis) in children, not suprasellar.
  • Presentation: Ataxia, gait disturbance, signs of increased intracranial pressure (due to 4th ventricle obstruction) like headache, vomiting, papilledema.
  • Histology: Small, round, blue cells with Homer–Wright rosettes — no wet keratin.
  • This child’s mass is suprasellar, causing visual and endocrine symptoms, which medulloblastomas do not.

Glioma (Option C):

  • Typical types relevant to the optic–hypothalamic region: Optic pathway gliomas, often in children (sometimes with NF1).
  • Presentation: Progressive visual loss, proptosis, and sometimes endocrine dysfunction if the hypothalamus is involved.
  • Histology: Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)–positive spindle cells, eosinophilic Rosenthal fibres (in pilocytic astrocytoma type) — no wet keratin.
  • While location could overlap, the hallmark histologic finding is completely different.

Pituitary Adenoma (Option D):

  • Epidemiology: Very rare in children; it mostly affects adults.
  • Presentation: Endocrine syndromes (hyperprolactinemia, Cushing’s disease, acromegaly), bitemporal hemianopia from optic chiasm compression.
  • Histology: Uniform polygonal pituitary cells in nests or cords; no keratin debris.
  • Age is atypical, histology doesn’t match, and pituitary adenomas don’t show “wet keratin.”

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency room with a penetrating injury and low blood pressure (hypotension). What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Emergency laparotomy

Explanation:

A penetrating injury accompanied by hypotension indicates likely internal bleeding or significant intra-abdominal injury, making urgent surgical exploration the priority, with emergency laparotomy being the gold standard treatment for hemodynamically unstable patients.

Computed Tomography (CT) scan (Option B): Requires the patient to be stable and takes time; not suitable in unstable patients with hypotension.

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage (DPL) (Option C): Useful in stable or borderline cases, but invasive and less commonly used now due to FAST ultrasound. Still, it can be considered if FAST is unavailable.
