Correct Option A - Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

Explanation:

  • Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but vascular tumor seen in young males causing nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and characteristic imaging findings like bowing of the posterior maxillary sinus wall due to mass effect.

Incorrect Options:

Antrochoanal polyp (Option B) typically lacks vascularity and epistaxis.

Rhinoscleroma (Option C) is a chronic granulomatous infection causing nasal obstruction but not typically epistaxis or bony changes.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D) causes nasal polyps but usually with surface granularity and no bony remodeling.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with difficulty in walking, bowing of legs, is underweight, and has minimal sun exposure. Which of the following government schemes addresses nutritional deficiencies in children under 6 years of age?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS)

Explanation:

  • ICDS focuses on nutritional supplementation, health, and preschool education for children under 6 years, addressing malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Mid-Day Meal Scheme targets school-age children, typically 6–14 years.

Option B: Anemia Mukt Bharat focuses broadly on anemia control across ages but is not specifically for under-6 children nutrition.

Option D: National Nutritional Deficiency Control Programme is outdated and subsumed under newer schemes.

questions.text: Identify the knot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Surgeons knot

Explanation: The given image depicts Surgeon’s knot

Knotting techniques:

  • Granny/ Slip Knots: A knot used to fasten a rope or line around an object, often deemed less dependable than the reef knot.

 

  • Square/ Reef knot: It is a standard knot with an extra throw for security.

  • Surgeon’s Knot: Extra security, prevents slippage (two-throw knot).

  • Aberdeen Knot: Secures final knot in continuous sutures.

 

  • Buried Knot: Used to secure the ends of absorbable sutures when a subcuticular suture technique is used to close the skin.
  • Monofilament Sutures: Require six throws for secure tying; leave 1–2 mm ends to prevent unraveling.

questions.text: A patient presents with guttate lesions in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy

  • The patient has guttate lesions in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other. Guttate lesions indicate endothelial cell loss, while bullous keratopathy results from corneal edema due to endothelial dysfunction. These are classical features of Fuchs’ endothelial dystrophy.
  • Fuchs’ endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, progressive corneal endothelial disorder.
  • Early sign: Guttae (drop-like excrescences on Descemet membrane) seen on slit lamp.
  • Late stage: Stromal edema → epithelial edema → bullae formation (bullous keratopathy).

Symptoms: Gradual, painless decrease in vision; glare; haloes; worse in the morning due to overnight edema.

Treatment:

  • Early: Hypertonic saline drops, hair dryer to reduce morning edema
  • Advanced: Keratoplasty (DSEK, DMEK, or PK)

Interstitial keratitis (Option B) – Chronic stromal inflammation, usually post-infectious (e.g., syphilis, HSV); presents with stromal haze and vascularization, not guttate lesions or bullous keratopathy.

Viral corneal ulcer (Option C) – Painful red eye with epithelial defect and stromal infiltrate; acute onset, not a chronic, painless, bilateral process.

Keratoconjunctivitis (Option D) – Inflammatory condition involving cornea and conjunctiva; presents with redness, pain, photophobia, discharge; not consistent with long-standing endothelial degeneration.

questions.text: History of pulsatile mass in the neck. Digital angiography image shown. Not filling on carotid compression. But refilling on releasing pressure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carotid Body tumour

Explanation: The image depicts Carotid body tumor, which is a highly vascular mass located at the carotid bifurcation. On digital subtraction angiography, the lyre sign (splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries) is seen.

  • The characteristic finding in this question is tumour blush that disappears with carotid compression (loss of arterial inflow) and reappears upon release - indicating that the tumour’s vascularity depends on carotid blood flow.

Carotid aneurysm (Option A): Would show persistent filling even with carotid compression if proximal to the aneurysm, and would not have the tumour blush pattern.

AV fistula (Option C): Demonstrates early venous filling on angiography, not the filling–emptying–refilling pattern described here.

Haemangioma (Option D): Typically a soft tissue vascular lesion, often cutaneous/subcutaneous, and not fed directly by carotid branches in this manner.

questions.text: A patient presents with skin cancer and hyperpigmentation that worsens with sunlight exposure. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is most likely defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nucleotide excision repair

Explanation:

Skin cancer and hyperpigmentation that worsen with sun exposure strongly indicate a defect in the Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) Pathway, which normally repairs UV-induced bulky DNA lesions like thymine dimers; such defects are seen in conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), marked by extreme UV sensitivity, pigmentation abnormalities, and a high risk of skin cancer.

  • This repair is required when,
    • Chemical damage to a segment occurs.
    • UV mediated Pyr Pyr dimerization is observed in a segment.
    • 30 bases are removed and then the correct bases are added.
  • A related nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway exists in humans, addressing UV-induced damage encountered during DNA synthesis.
  • Transcription-coupled repair, a type of NER, specifically targets lesions that obstruct RNA synthesis.

  • Clinical application:
    • Pyrimidine dimers can form in human skin cells exposed to unfiltered sunlight.
    • In xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a genetic disorder, the inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage leads to the accumulation of mutations and a heightened risk of developing early and multiple skin cancers.
    • XP results from defects in genes coding for proteins necessary for NER of UV damage

Incorrect Options:

Base excision repair (Option B) fixes small, non-bulky base lesions (e.g., oxidative damage).

Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) (Option C) repairs double-strand breaks, unrelated to UV damage.

Mismatch repair (Option D) corrects replication errors, not UV-induced damage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman with a previous cesarean section is undergoing a trial of vaginal delivery at 39 weeks. She is in active labor with 8 cm cervical dilation and fetal station at -1. Continuous fetal monitoring reveals fetal bradycardia, and maternal pulse is 110/min. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Emergency cesarean section

Explanation: The correct answer is emergency cesarean section because sudden fetal bradycardia with maternal tachycardia in a woman undergoing VBAC is highly suggestive of impending uterine rupture, a critical obstetric emergency.

  • This situation requires immediate delivery before complete rupture occurs, as both maternal and fetal morbidity/mortality can escalate rapidly.
  • The fetal station at –1 indicates the head is not low enough for instrumental delivery, so emergency laparotomy with cesarean is the safest choice.

Continue monitoring and wait (Option B): Delaying action risks progression from impending to complete rupture, leading to catastrophic hemorrhage and fetal demise.

Administer oxytocin to augment labor (Option C): Strongly contraindicated as it can precipitate full rupture by increasing uterine pressure.

Perform operative vaginal delivery (Option D): Not possible at station –1 and inappropriate when rupture is suspected. Surgical access is needed for both delivery and uterine assessment.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 2-year history of anorexia, epigastric pain, jaundice, and itching (pruritis). On examination, the gallbladder is palpable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Ca of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ca of the head of the pancreas

Explanation:

Prolonged anorexia, epigastric pain, jaundice, and pruritis with a palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier’s sign) indicate chronic biliary obstruction, most commonly caused by carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

CA Pancreas

  • Symptoms:
    • Jaundice secondary to obstruction is the most common symptom
    • Characteristically painless, but may be associated with nausea and epigastric discomfort
    • Pruritus, dark urine and pale stools with steatorrhea
    • Weight loss
  • Signs:
    • Courvoisier’s sign - palpable, non-tender gallbladder (Option D)
    • Palpable liver and ascites
    • Diabetes mellitus depending on the location of tumor

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option A): Although gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice and a palpable gallbladder, it is less common and usually presents with more localized symptoms.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option B) rarely causes biliary obstruction or a palpable gallbladder.

Cholelithiasis (gallstones) (Option C) usually causes episodic pain and does not present with a palpable gallbladder or chronic jaundice.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of steps in a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Randomisation → Manipulation → Follow-up → Assessment:

Explanation:

  • A Randomized Controlled Trial is considered the gold standard in clinical research because it minimizes bias and ensures comparability between study groups.
    • Randomisation: Participants are assigned to intervention or control groups using random methods, ensuring equal distribution of confounding factors.
    • Manipulation (Intervention): The experimental treatment or procedure is applied to the intervention group.
    • Follow-up: Participants are monitored over time to observe effects and detect adverse events.
    • Assessment: Outcomes are measured and analyzed to determine the effect of the intervention.
  • Other sequences (Options A, C, D) wrongly order randomisation, intervention, or assessment steps, compromising study validity.

questions.text: A person with jaundice presented with a history of bleeding, and symptoms normalised after giving a Vitamin K injection. The probable cause is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Biliary obstruction

Explanation:

The patient's jaundice and bleeding tendency that resolved with vitamin K suggest a vitamin K deficiency due to biliary obstruction, which impairs bile flow and subsequently the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin K, leading to defective clotting.

  • Fat-soluble vitamin that acts as a coenzyme or prosthetic group for gamma-carboxylase.
  • Calcium-dependent proteins that rely on Vitamin K:
    • Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.
    • Anticoagulant factors like protein C and S.
    • Osteocalcin (promotes bone mineralization by depositing calcium).
  • Forms of Vitamin K:
    • Phylloquinone (K1): Found in green vegetables, this form has an isoprenoid side chain with 20 carbons.
    • Menaquinones (K2): Synthesized by intestinal bacteria, these have varying side chain lengths and an isoprenoid side chain containing 30 carbons, which is lipid soluble.
    • Menadione (K3): A synthetic form which is water-soluble. Menadione and menadione diacetate can be metabolized into phylloquinone.
  • Vitamin K exists in two forms: Epoxide and Hydroquinone form.
  • Functions:
    • Blood Clotting.
    • Bone Health - Carboxylating glutamate to glutamic acid in proteins like osteocalcin is involved in bone mineralization.

Incorrect Options:

Alpha antitrypsin deficiency (Option B) can cause liver disease and jaundice, but does not cause vitamin K–responsive bleeding.

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option C) causes liver inflammation, but bleeding due to this is typically from synthetic liver dysfunction, not corrected by vitamin K.

Factor XI deficiency (Option D) is a hereditary bleeding disorder, not related to vitamin K or jaundice, and not corrected by vitamin K injection.

questions.text: In a village, several people developed dysentery after consuming raw milk. On laboratory examination, gram-negative, curved rods with polymorphonuclear infiltration were found in stool samples. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Campylobacter jejuni

Explanation:

Campylobacter jejuni:

  • Morphology: Gram-negative, curved/spiral rods, motile with polar flagella.
  • Reservoir: GI tract of poultry, cattle; raw milk is a common source.
  • Pathogenesis: Invades intestinal mucosa → causes inflammation and ulceration.
  • Clinical features: Fever, abdominal cramps, bloody diarrhea.
  • Complications: Guillain–Barré syndrome, reactive arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Gram-positive rods; causes watery diarrhea, rarely dysentery.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Gram-positive cocci; preformed toxin → vomiting and watery diarrhea, no PMNs in stool.

Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Option C): Gram-negative curved rods, but linked to seafood, not raw milk, and usually causes watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with nocturnal perianal itching. The image below shows the organism identified on an adhesive tape test. Mother saw a worm coming out from the anal canal. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enterobius vermicularis

Explanation:

  • The parasite infestation in the given scenario is of Enterobius vermicularis or the pinworm which causes intense itching in the perianal region due to the female worm laying eggs in this region at night. The infective stage of this is the embryonated egg. The eggs are often observed on the perianal skin, and when the child scratches the area, they can spread the eggs to others or other surfaces. The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained

Enterobius vermicularis / Pinworm / Threadworm

Epidemiology:

  • The most common age group being school children.
  • Infections can persist for years due to auto-infective cycles.
  • Factors contributing to infection include:
    • Overcrowding
    • Impaired hygiene
    • Poor personal care practices (such as nail-biting and inadequate handwashing).

Morphology

Adult worm
  • The adults are short, white, and fusiform, resembling bits of white thread.
  • The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like structures called cervical alae, which are transversely striated.

Female worm

  • Females are long.
  • The posterior third tapers into a thin, pointed, pin-like tail.
  • Females are oviparous.

Male worm
  • The posterior end is tightly curved ventrally, sharply truncated, and has a prominent copulatory spicule.

Eggs

  • The eggs are colorless and not bile-stained
  • They float in saturated salt solution and have an elongated ovoid shape.
  • Each egg contains a tadpole-shaped, coiled embryo that becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited.

 

Scotch-tape test:

A piece of clear tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, typically overnight. The tape is then examined under a microscope for pinworm eggs.

 

Life cycle:

  • Enterobius vermicularis spends the entire lifecycle in humans.
  • It has no intermediate hosts and does not undergo systemic migration.
  • The eggs hatch in the intestine, and the larvae enter the caecum and mature into adults.
  • The male worm does not migrate and most often dies after mating and is passed in the feces.
  • The female worm migrates to the rectum from the colon and travels to the perianal skin at night to lay its sticky eggs and dies after laying all eggs or gets crushed due to scratching.

Pathogenicity:

  • The embryonated egg is the infective form.
  • The disease thus caused is called enterobiasis, which is more common in children than in adults.
  • It affects females > males.
  • The infection occurs in two ways:
    • Exogenous autoinfection is where the eggs are transferred from the perianal region to the mouth by nails after scratching the region.
    • Endogenous autoinfection/retro-infection is where the larva migrates retrograde and travels back into the colon after hatching in the perianal skin.

Incorrect Options:

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option B): hookworm; causes anemia, not nocturnal itching.

Hymenolepis nana (Option C): dwarf tapeworm; causes abdominal discomfort, not perianal itching.

Trichuris trichiura (Option D) (whipworm): While whipworms can infect the intestines, they are not typically associated with perianal itching or the nocturnal symptoms described. Their main symptoms involve abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally rectal prolapse.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the emergency room with severe dyspnea and altered mental status. An arterial blood gas (ABG) is drawn with the following results:


	pH: 7.28
	PaCO2: 60 mmHg
	HCO3-: 28 mEq/L
	Na+: 142 mEq/L
	Cl-: 100 mEq/L


Based on these results, what is the calculated anion gap?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – 14 mEq/L

Explanation:

The Anion Gap (AG) calculated in the above scenario is 14mEq/L.

  • It measures the difference between measured cations and anions in the serum.
  • Formula:

  • In above ques: AG=142−(100+28) = 142−128 = 14 mEq/L​.

questions.text: A known type 1 diabetic presents with glucose 799 mg/dL, Na⁺ 128 mEq/L, Cl⁻ 88 mEq/L, and signs of dehydration. Which of the following is NOT used in the initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3% Saline

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation points towards DKA

  • In DKA, the initial management focuses on:
    • Fluid resuscitation with isotonic saline (0.9% NaCl) to correct dehydration.
    • Insulin infusion to correct hyperglycemia and ketosis.
    • Potassium monitoring and replacement as insulin therapy and fluids can cause hypokalemia.

Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022):

3% hypertonic saline is not indicated unless there is severe symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological symptoms (usually Na⁺ < 120 mEq/L and acute onset). In this case, hyponatremia is dilutional and corrects with normal saline and DKA management.

questions.text: What is correct regarding this suture ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Monoflament

Explanation: The image depicts Polydioxanone suture and most appropriate answer would be monofilament suture.

Polydioxanone (PDS):

  • Raw material: Para-dioxanone polymer (Synthetic)
  • Monofilament
  • Absorption rate: Complete absorption at 180 days
  • Mild tissue reaction
  • Tensile strength retention in vivo:
    • 70% remains at 2 weeks
    • 50% remains at 4 weeks
    • 14% remains at 8 weeks
  • Uses: Instances where slightly longer wound support is required
  • Lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus

Types of sutures:

 

  • Based on the number of strands:

 

Monofilament

Polyfilament

Single strand of fiber

Multiple strands braided together

Smooth & strong

Easier to handle

Decreased chance of bacterial infection

Increased risk of infection due to the lodging of bacteria in crevices

Knots tied may become loose (6-8 knots)

Knots are stable (3-4 knots)

E.g.:

  • Prolene
  • Ethilon
  • Nylon
  • PDS

E.g.:

  • Silk
  • Linen
  • Polyglycolic acid (Dexon)

Polyglactin 910 (Vicryl) is an absorbable polyfilament suture.

Polyglycolic acid (Dexon) is an absorbable polyfilament suture.

questions.text: If you need to diagnose a syndromic illness such as meningitis, which of the following diagnostic techniques is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiplex PCR

Explanation:

When diagnosing a syndromic illness such as meningitis, which may be caused by various pathogens including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, Multiplex PCR is used because it can simultaneously detect multiple causative agents.

  • Amplifies multiple DNA targets in one reaction using several primer sets.
  • Saves time and reduces costs by testing multiple pathogens simultaneously.
  • Commonly used in clinical diagnostics and genetic testing.
  • Requires careful primer design to avoid interference.
  • Offers high sensitivity and specificity when well optimized.
  • Ideal for syndromic testing where multiple pathogens may be involved.

Incorrect Options:

Uniplex PCR (Option B) detects only one target per reaction, making it less efficient for syndromic testing.

Attributed PCR (Option C) is not a commonly used term in molecular diagnostics.

Nested PCR (Option D) is a two-step PCR designed to increase sensitivity and specificity but usually targets a single pathogen per test.

questions.text: A woman develops atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) after vaginal delivery that does not respond to initial medical management. What is the next best step in management in labour room?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bakri balloon tamponade

Explanation: The correct answer is Bakri balloon tamponade because after failed medical management of atonic PPH, the next escalation in a hemodynamically stable patient - especially in the labour room is a minimally invasive mechanical method to tamponade bleeding.

  • Bakri balloon (or condom catheter in resource-limited settings) provides direct intrauterine pressure, promotes clot formation, and buys time before more invasive surgical options.

 

Management of PPH:

 

Mechanical compression techniques:

Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices

Intrauterine hemorrhage-control devices are typically used for uterine atony unresponsive to medications and massage, often as a step before more invasive surgery.

Contraindications:

  • Allergy to any device component or packing material.
  • Retained Products: Should not replace evacuation of retained pregnancy tissue.

Intrauterine Balloon Tamponade

Types: Multiple balloon catheters used for intrauterine tamponade.

Sengstaken tube. Examples:

  • Bakri, BT-cath, ebb complete;
  • Foley's catheter (can hold up to 100 ml of fluids)
  • Condoms

Mechanism: Hydrostatic pressure applied inward to outward against uterine wall to reduce blood flow and facilitate clotting.

Vacuum-Induced Tamponade

Mechanism: Applies low-level intrauterine vacuum (70-90 mmHg) to evacuate blood and clot, facilitating uterine contractions.

Intrauterine Packing

Plain Gauze/Laparotomy Sponges: Traditional packing method; Replaced by balloon tamponade due to its effectiveness.

Hemostatic Gauze: Gauze with additional hemostatic mechanisms

Compressed Mini-Sponges: Novel device.

 

Compression sutures (Option A): Used during laparotomy, but not feasible in the labour room without surgical exposure.

 

Devascularisation procedures: (Option C)

Uterine Compression Sutures

Techniques involving sutures to compress the uterus and control bleeding.

B-Lynch Suture
  • Envelops and compresses the uterus; most common technique.
  • Effective for uterine atony, simple to learn, safe
  • May increase risk of Asherman syndrome.

Hayman Technique
  • Uses two to four vertical compression sutures without hysterotomy.
  • Suitable after vaginal birth.

Pereira Technique
  • Involves transverse and longitudinal sutures around the uterus without entering the uterine cavity.
  • Requires care to avoid damaging blood vessels, ureters, and fallopian tubes; manual compression before tying sutures.

Cho Technique
  • Utilizes multiple squares or rectangles for uterine compression.


 

Uterine Devascularization

  • Progressive ligation of more proximal arteries to control uterine bleeding.
  • May require a hysterectomy if unsuccessful.

Bilateral Uterine Artery Ligation
  • Ligation of the ascending branch of each uterine artery at the lateral border of the uterus.

 

Ovarian and Uterine Artery Anastomosis Ligation
  • Ligation of the anastomosis between ovarian and uterine arteries on each side.

Bilateral Internal Iliac Artery Ligation
  • Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery on one or both sides to reduce blood flow to the uterus.


 

Hysterectomy (Option D): It is a last resort for PPH, it may be necessary in cases where other measures have failed or when there are compelling reasons to remove the uterus.

questions.text: A man is trapped in a tunnel for 5 consecutive days without access to food but survives. What is the primary source of energy for his brain during this period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ketosis

Explanation:

  • When a person is deprived of food for 3–5 days, the brain adapts by using ketone bodies—primarily β-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate—produced through Ketosis as its main energy source, thereby conserving muscle protein from being broken down for gluconeogenesis.

KETOSIS

Causes

  • Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Untreated diabetes mellitus → Insulin deficiency → Increases lipolysis and fatty acid oxidation → Raises acetyl CoA levels → Overproduction of ketone bodies (relies on fat metabolism for energy).
  • Starvation:
    • Reduced dietary glucose shifts oxaloacetate to gluconeogenesis.
    • Increased lipolysis converts excess acetyl CoA to ketone bodies.
    • High glucagon levels promote ketogenesis.
    • Limited glucose boosts free fatty acid mobilization, with the liver converting them to ketones, regulated by carnitine palmitoyltransferase-I (CPT-I).
  • Hyperemesis in early pregnancy can also cause ketosis.

Ketone Bodies
  • Produced in the liver
  • Utilized by extrahepatic tissues due to the absence of Thiophorase enzyme in the liver

Tissues that use Ketone Bodies
  • Almost all tissues except:
    • Liver
    • Red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Tissues that prefer ketone bodies:
    • Heart muscle
    • Renal cortex
    • Placenta
  • Tissues that use ketone bodies only in the absence of glucose:
    • Skeletal muscle
    • Brain
  • Additional Tissues Using Ketone Bodies
    • Intestinal mucosal cells
    • Adipocytes

Enzyme Involved
  • Thiophorase: Converts acetoacetate to acetoacetyl CoA

Fatty Acids as Primary Energy Source During Starvation
  • Skeletal muscles
  • Heart
  • Liver

Energy Production Pathway
  • Acetoacetyl CoA enters the beta-oxidation pathway to produce energy

Incorrect Options:

Gluconeogenesis (Option A) is active early in fasting, but not the main source for brain energy after 5 days.

Glycogenolysis (Option B): Liver glycogen is depleted within ~24 hours of fasting.

Lipolysis (Option D): Breaks down fat into free fatty acids and glycerol, but fatty acids can't cross the blood-brain barrier — only ketones can.

questions.text: A 24-hour-old baby with severe respiratory distress was admitted to the ICU. A chest X-ray of the neonate is given. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

  • The X-ray shows multiple air-filled bowel loops within the left hemithorax with a mediastinal shift to the right and absence of the normal diaphragmatic contour on that side suggestive of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)

  • Definition: Developmental defect in the diaphragm → abdominal viscera herniate into the thoracic cavity.
  • Most common type: Bochdalek hernia (posterolateral defect, usually left-sided, ~85%).
  • Embryology/Anatomy: Failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal by the pleuroperitoneal membrane during the 8th–10th week of gestation.
  • Pathophysiology: Herniation compresses the developing lung → pulmonary hypoplasia + pulmonary hypertension → severe respiratory distress soon after birth.

 

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM)

Congenital Lobar Emphysema (CLE)

Neonatal Pneumonia

Key Pathology

 

Defect in diaphragm → bowel loops in thorax

Hamartomatous overgrowth of terminal bronchioles

Overinflation of a lobe due to bronchial cartilage defect or obstruction

Infection (often GBS)

CXR Findings

 

Multiple air-filled bowel loops in thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift, absent diaphragmatic outline, scaphoid abdomen

Multicystic mass with varying cyst sizes; does not connect to abdomen

Hyperlucent overexpanded lobe, mediastinal shift, no cysts or bowel gas

Diffuse or focal consolidation, ground-glass opacity, air bronchograms

Onset

At birth

At birth or later

 

At birth or delayed

Variable

Location

 

Usually left posterolateral (Bochdalek)

Single lobe

 

Most often left upper lobe

Any lobe

CPAM (Option A): Cystic lesions within lung, but not organized bowel gas pattern with clear loops.

Congenital lobar emphysema (Option C): Overinflated lobe, no bowel loops or diaphragmatic defect.

Neonatal pneumonia (Option D): Diffuse or focal opacities, no bowel gas in thorax.

questions.text: A 3 year old child was brought to OPD with complain of dysuria and ballooning on micturition and examination as given below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) True phimosis

Explanation: The image depicts true phimosis occurs when the preputial orifice is abnormally narrow due to fibrosis, preventing retraction of the foreskin over the glans. This leads to ballooning during urination as urine collects under the foreskin before exiting.

  • In children, true phimosis is usually due to chronic inflammation or scarring, and unlike physiological phimosis of infants, it does not resolve spontaneously and often requires surgical intervention (circumcision).

Balanitis xerotica obliterans (Option A): This is a chronic inflammatory skin condition (lichen sclerosus) causing white, atrophic patches and progressive foreskin tightening, more common in older boys and adults, not the classic cause in a 3-year-old.

Recurrent balanoposthitis (Option C): Involves repeated foreskin and glans inflammation with redness, swelling, and discharge — absent in this case.

Recurrent urinary tract infections (Option D): While phimosis can predispose to UTIs, the primary presentation here is mechanical obstruction with ballooning, not multiple proven UTIs.

questions.text: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody in systemic sclerosis is most commonly associated with which of the following manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Interstitial Lung Disease

Explanation: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody is strongly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and a high risk of developing interstitial lung disease (ILD), particularly pulmonary fibrosis.

  • This antibody is both a marker of disease severity and a predictor of poorer prognosis in systemic sclerosis.

Pulmonary Features in Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Major Forms of Lung Involvement:
    • Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) and Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) are the primary lung issues and leading causes of SSc-related death.
    • The coexistence of ILD and PAH worsens survival rates significantly.
  • Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD):
    • Evidence of ILD on HRCT in up to 65% of patients, with clinically significant ILD in 16–43%.
    • Risk factors: Male sex, African-American race, diffuse skin involvement, severe GERD, and presence of Scl-70 autoantibodies.
    • Progressive early decline in FVC (within 3–5 years).
    • Symptoms: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, dry cough, and Velcro crackles at lung bases.
    • HRCT shows lower lobe subpleural reticular opacities and ground-glass opacities; the extent of ILD on HRCT predicts progression and mortality.
    • PFTs show restrictive defects and reduced DLCO, often with exercise desaturation.
  • Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH):
    • Affects 8–12% of SSc patients as a late complication, often coexisting with ILD.
    • Defined by elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure (≥20 mmHg) with normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (≤15 mmHg).
    • Risk factors: Limited cutaneous disease, older age at onset, and certain autoantibodies (e.g., anti-centromere).
    • Symptoms progress from exertional dyspnea to angina, syncope, and right heart failure.
    • Exam findings: Loud pulmonic component of S2, tricuspid regurgitation murmur, elevated JVP, peripheral edema.
    • Screening: Annual echocardiography; cardiac catheterization for definitive diagnosis.
  • Other Pulmonary Complications:
    • Includes aspiration pneumonitis, pulmonary hemorrhage, obliterative bronchiolitis, pleural reactions, chest wall fibrosis, spontaneous pneumothorax, and increased risk of lung cancer.

Cardiac Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Detected in 10–50% of SSc patients, more common in diffuse cutaneous SSc (dcSSc) than limited cutaneous SSc (lcSSc).
  • Cardiac involvement correlates with worse outcomes in SSc.
  • Types of Involvement:
    • Pericardial: Includes pericarditis, pericardial effusions, constrictive pericarditis, and rarely, cardiac tamponade.
    • Myocardial: Patchy myocardial fibrosis due to microvascular involvement, vasospasm, and ischemia-reperfusion injury leading to left ventricular systolic or diastolic dysfunction and potentially heart failure.
    • Endocardial: Often silent but may contribute to overall dysfunction.
    • Conduction Abnormalities:
      • Common conduction system fibrosis, with potential heart block, premature ventricular contractions, atrial fibrillation, and supraventricular tachycardia.
    • Myocarditis:
      • Acute or subacute myocarditis may lead to left ventricular dysfunction, best detected by cardiac MRI or endomyocardial biopsy.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option B): Common in systemic sclerosis, but it is not specifically linked to anti-Scl-70; seen in both limited and diffuse types, often associated with anti-centromere antibodies in limited cutaneous form.

Calcinosis cutis (Option C): More often linked to the limited form of systemic sclerosis and the CREST variant, not to anti-Scl-70.

Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (Option D): “Watermelon stomach” occurs in systemic sclerosis but is not specifically correlated with anti-Scl-70; more frequent in limited disease.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with lymph node swelling. She has a history of toxoplasmosis infection 5 years ago and is IgG positive. What should be the next step?

choices.text: Do amniotic sampling to find if fetus is infected or not

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reassurance, continue pregnancy

Explanation:

  • Toxoplasma IgG positivity with past infection (several years ago) indicates immunity and no active infection.
  • Once infected, the risk of congenital transmission is only present during the acute phase of maternal infection.
  • Chronic/past infection does not pose a risk to the fetus and requires no intervention.
  • Therefore, reassurance and routine antenatal care are appropriate.

 

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission.

 

As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

 

Pre-pregnancy

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)
 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.
 

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

 

Diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis

Antenatal

USG

  • Done at 20-24 weeks of gestation and repeated every 2-4 weeks
  • It helps detect lesions of congenital infection, such as
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Ascites

Serology

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) or IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay) is done using maternal serum to detect IgM and IgG

PCR
  • Amniotic fluid can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA, which can confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not done routinely as it is invasive and expensive, and other safer options are available.

Postnatal diagnosis

Serology

Newborn Sera and maternal sera are both used to detect

  • IgG >= 1000: Possible infection
  • IgM >= 1:4 after 2 weeks of age: Indicates probable diagnosis
  • IgA: Disappears within 10 days of birth; thus, persistence indicates postnatal infection
 

Sabin-Feldman test - Complement fixation test

Other tests

  • Animal inoculation (no longer done for clinical diagnosis)
  • Skin test of Frenkel
  • Microscopy of samples to detect tachyzoites using Giemsa or PAS

 

Congenital anomalies risk is high (Option A): Risk is only high with acute infection during pregnancy, not with past resolved infection.
 

Do amniotic sampling to find if fetus is infected or not (Option C): Unnecessary since there is no evidence of recent infection; IgM would be positive in acute infection.
 

Start treatment (Option D): Antiparasitic treatment is indicated only in acute infection during pregnancy to reduce fetal risk, not in past infection.

questions.text: During autopsy, a body shows curved scratch marks below the right angle of the mandible, three grouped bruises on the left side of the neck below the thyroid cartilage, and additional bruises over the head, posterior shoulder, backside of the trunk, and hip crests. Fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage present. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Throttling

Explanation:

  • Throttling refers to manual strangulation using the hands.

  • The described autopsy findings — curved scratch marks from fingernails, localized grouped bruises from finger pressure, and fracture of the superior horn of the thyroid cartilage — are classic for forceful compression of the neck by human hands.

  • Associated bruises on other body parts often indicate a struggle.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Garroting uses a tightened ligature, producing a horizontal mark.

Option C - Mugging is an assault type, not a pathological cause.

Option D - Ligature strangulation causes patterned marks from the cord, absent here.

questions.text: Group A Streptococcus is the most common cause of bacterial pharyngitis in school-aged children. Which of the following bacterial components is primarily responsible for its attachment to fibronectin on the epithelial lining of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lipoteichoic acid

Explanation:

  • Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) attaches to the epithelial lining of the pharynx using lipoteichoic acid (LTA).
  • LTA is anchored in the bacterial cell membrane and extends through the peptidoglycan layer.
  • It binds to fibronectin on host epithelial cells → facilitates initial colonization.

Incorrect Options:

Lipoprotein (Option A): Found in bacterial membranes; functions mainly in nutrient transport and immune evasion, not primary attachment to fibronectin.

Capsule (Option C): Composed of hyaluronic acid in GAS; helps evade phagocytosis, not for initial adherence.

Flagella (Option D): GAS is non-motile, so it has no flagella.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl and a 23-year-old boy undergo medical examination following allegations of rape made by the girl’s parents. The girl states the sexual act was consensual, and no injuries are found on examination. According to the law, what is the legal status of the consent in this case?

choices.text: Consent is invalid as the girl is under 18 years
No punishment since the act was consensual
No punishment since there are no injuries
Parents must prove the act was non-consensual

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Consent is invalid as the girl is under 18 years:

Explanation:

  • Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act and the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), the age of consent for sexual activity is 18 years.
  • Any sexual act with a person below 18 years is legally considered statutory rape, regardless of actual consent or absence of injuries.
  • The intent of the law is to protect minors from exploitation, assuming they cannot give legally valid consent for sexual activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - No punishment since the act was consensual: Incorrect, because in statutory rape, consent is legally irrelevant if the person is under 18.

Option C - No punishment since there are no injuries: Incorrect, as absence of injury does not affect the offence; penetration alone suffices for rape charges under the law.

Option D - Parents must prove the act was non-consensual: Incorrect, as non-consent need not be proven for minors under 18; the act itself is punishable.

questions.text: Based on the given image, which type of injury is shown according to the Bismuth-Strasberg classification:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type A

Explanation:

According to the Bismuth-Strasberg classification, the image shows a Type A injury, which involves a cystic duct stump leak or leakage from small ducts in the liver bed, and is the most common type, typically occurring without damage to the major bile ducts.

Bismuth classification for biliary strictures

Type A

Bile leak from cystic duct or liver bed (Option A)

Type B

Occlusion of the right segmental duct (Option B ruled out)

Type C

Bile leak from divided right segmental duct (Option C ruled out)

Type D

Lateral injury to the common hepatic duct (Option D ruled out)

Type E

E1: Main bile duct injury, more than 2 cm from the confluence

E2: Main bile duct injury, less than 2 cm from the confluence

E3: Hilar injury with intact confluence

E4: Injury involving the confluence; right and left hepatic ducts are separated

E5: Injury of aberrant right sectoral duct with simultaneous injury of the main bile duct.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with palpitations and breathlessness that started 4 hours ago and on examination is found to have and irregularly irregular pulse. He has no history of diabetes or other comorbidities. What is the most appropitate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Initiate rate control

Explanation:

  • This patient with new-onset atrial fibrillation (symptoms <48 hours) and stable vital signs should be initially managed with rate control to relieve symptoms and prevent rapid ventricular response before considering rhythm control or anticoagulation.

 

Atrial Fibrillation

Features

  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.

  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly

  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse

  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present

  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure.

  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).

  • Class III Drugs:

    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail.

    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.

  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention.

  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:

    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).

    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours; anticoagulation required if AF ≥48 hours.

    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.

  • Rate Control:

    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).

    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.

    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

Thromboprophylaxis

  • Anticoagulation: Required for stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium.

    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.

    • DOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed.

  • Risk Assessment:

    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2.

    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.

  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Transesophageal echo is not indicated immediately because symptom duration is short and no planned delayed cardioversion.

Option B: Emergent cardioversion is generally not the first step unless unstable

Option C: Anticoagulation is important but not the very first step before rate or rhythm control; it depends on risk stratification.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain. A lateral lumbar spine X-ray is provided. Based on the radiological findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spondylolisthesis

Explanation: The image depicts slippage of vertebra over the other and most likely diagnosis is Spondylolisthesis.

 

Clinical Features of Different Types of Spondylolisthesis

Feature

Isthmic

Congenital

Degenerative

Symptoms
  • Asymptomatic or low back pain.
  • History of trauma in 50% of cases.
  • Common in both adults and children.
  • Pain in lower back, buttocks, legs, and toes.
  • Known as pseudospondylolisthesis.
  • Intermittent symptoms, especially in the elderly.
  • More common in women (5 times) and affects 4-10% of the population.
  • Pain in the back, buttock, or thigh.

Deformity
  • Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • Palpable step at L5–S1.(Step sign)
  • Short torso, protruding abdomen.
  • Transverse furrow at L5.
  • Vertical sacrum.
  • Flat buttocks and hamstring tightness.
  • Prominent L5 spinous process.
  • Scoliosis present in 13%.
  • Scoliosis and pelvic waddle.
  • Flat buttocks.
  • Stiffness of the spine; limited bending.
  • Stiffness of spine.

Neurological Issues
  • Rare involvement of L5 nerve root.
  • Involvement of L5 or S1 nerve root; L5 involvement is rare.
  • Neurological claudication.
  • Commonly affects L3–4.

 

 

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis

Spondylolisthesis
  • Resembles a Scottish dog
  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)
  • Defect without vertebral displacement
  • Separated Head and Neck
  • Defect with vertebral displacement

 

 

Spondylitis (Option A): Would show inflammatory changes (e.g., squaring of vertebral bodies, syndesmophytes in ankylosing spondylitis) rather than vertebral slippage.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): Primary malignant bone tumor, rare in spine, would present with destructive bony lesion and soft tissue mass, not a clean slip.

Vertebral fracture (Option D): Would show cortical disruption or collapse of vertebral body without smooth anterior translation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with a painless, gradually increasing mass located lateral to the lateral canthus, present for the past 10 years. On examination, the mass is non-tender and slowly progressive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Dermoid cyst

  • A painless, slowly progressive, lateral canthal mass present since childhood suggests a congenital lesion at a suture line, which is most characteristic of a dermoid cyst.
  • Dermoid cysts are congenital choristomas caused by ectodermal tissue being trapped along embryonic suture lines, most commonly at the frontozygomatic suture. They contain epidermis and dermal appendages like hair follicles and sebaceous glands. The lesion is firm, non-tender, and slow-growing.
  • Imaging (CT/MRI) shows a well-circumscribed cyst with fat density.
  • Definitive management is surgical excision with intact capsule to prevent recurrence and inflammation.

Capillary hemangioma (Option B): Appears in infancy, is vascular, red/bluish, and rapidly proliferates before involution — not a 10-year static mass.

Lacrimal gland tumor (Option C): Usually in adults, causes superolateral orbital swelling with globe displacement; may have pain.

Epidermoid cyst (Option D): Contains only epidermis without dermal appendages; location and imaging features make dermoid more likely in this case.

questions.text: Benralizumab acts on which receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IL 5:

Explanation:

  • Benralizumab specifically binds to the α-subunit of the interleukin-5 receptor (IL-5Rα) present on eosinophils and basophils. By binding to IL-5Rα, it blocks IL-5 signalling and also triggers antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC), leading to direct depletion of eosinophils.
  • This reduces airway inflammation in eosinophilic asthma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - IL-4: Targeted by drugs like dupilumab, used in atopic dermatitis and asthma.

  • IL-4 is important in IgE class switching and Th2 immune responses — not the main target for eosinophil depletion.

Option C - IL-1: Blocked by anakinra (IL-1 receptor antagonist) and others, used in autoinflammatory conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic JIA). IL-1 blockade has no major role in eosinophilic asthma.

Option D - TNF alpha: Targeted by drugs like infliximab, adalimumab, and etanercept in autoimmune diseases (RA, IBD, psoriasis). TNF-α inhibitors are not used for eosinophil-specific asthma management.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent migraine attacks. She has been using sumatriptan for abortive treatment, but recently developed chest tightness and tingling sensations after its use. She has family history of CAD. She now requests a preventive therapy to reduce the frequency of migraine attacks. Which of the following is the most appropriate choice for migraine prophylaxis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Propranolol:

Explanation:

Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonist used for acute migraine treatment but can cause chest tightness and other vasoconstrictive side effects, especially risky in patients with CAD or cardiovascular risk factors. This patient’s chest symptoms and family history of CAD indicate caution with vasoconstrictive agents.

Propranolol:

Class: Non-selective β-blocker.

Role: First-line drug for migraine prophylaxis.

Mechanism: Reduces cortical excitability, stabilises vascular tone, and dampens sympathetic overactivity.

  • Patient has a history of migraine and needs prevention, not acute relief.
  • No direct contraindication to β-blockers is mentioned.
  • Family history of CAD makes β-blockers even more favourable, as they may offer some cardioprotective effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Topiramate: Also first-line for migraine prophylaxis. It could still be used, but propranolol is often the first pick when CAD risk exists because it benefits both conditions. Topiramate has more CNS side effects (cognitive slowing, paresthesias) and no cardiac protection.

Option C - Ergotamine: Used in acute migraine treatment, not prophylaxis. It is a potent vasoconstrictor and increases the risk of myocardial ischemia. Hence, it is contraindicated in patients with CAD or significant CAD risk.

Option D - Naratriptan: Used in acute migraine relief, like sumatriptan. It is a vasoconstrictor, contraindicated in CAD and high-risk patients.

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with cervical cancer is found to have unilateral hydroureteronephrosis on imaging due to tumor invasion. What is the FIGO stage of her disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage IIIB

Explanation: According to FIGO staging for cervical cancer, hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney due to tumor invasion indicates stage IIIB, regardless of whether it is unilateral or bilateral.

FIGO staging of cervical cancer:

Stage

Description

Stage I

I: Cancer limited to cervix (extension to the corpus is disregarded)

A: micro-invasive (<5mm deep)

  • A1: <3 mm deep
  • A2: 3-4 mm deep

B: Macro invasive (≥5 mm deep)

  • B1: size of tumor <2 cm
  • B2: size of tumor 2 - 4 cm
  • B3: size of tumor ≥ 4 cm

Stage II

II: Cancer spreads to upper 2/3rd of vagina

A: Without parametrial involvement

  • A1: size of tumor <4 cm
  • A2: size of tumor ≥4 cm

B: With parametrial involvement

Stage III

III: Cancer involving lower 1/3rd of vagina

A: Pelvic side wall not involved

B: Pelvic side wall involved or presence of hydroureter/hydronephrosis

C: Involvement of lymph nodes

  • C1: Pelvic lymph nodes
  • C2: Para-aortic lymph nodes

Stage IV

IV: Metastasis

A: Regional metastasis involving bladder or bowel

B: Distant metastasis or superficial inguinal lymph nodes involvement

questions.text: A patient presents with the following lesions with a burning sensation on eating spicy food. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lithium

Explanation:

  • Given the presentation, oral lesions with burning sensation, especially on eating spicy food, the most likely diagnosis is oral lichenoid reaction or lichenoid stomatitis, which is a known adverse effect of lithium.

  • Adverse effect: Chronic lithium therapy can cause lichenoid mucosal lesions (white, lacy, reticular patches) often with burning on spicy or acidic foods.

  • Mechanism: Hypersensitivity reaction to the drug, producing lesions clinically and histologically similar to oral lichen planus.

  • Common sites: Buccal mucosa, tongue, gingiva.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Beta blockers: Can cause lichenoid drug eruptions, but these are more commonly cutaneous rather than mucosal. Oral involvement is rare.

Option C - Fluconazole: Antifungal; does not cause oral lichenoid reactions. In fact, it’s used to treat oral candidiasis, not cause it.

Option D - Ciprofloxacin: Can cause photosensitivity, tendon injury, CNS effects — oral lichenoid lesions are not a typical side effect.

questions.text:
A patient underwent ileal resection and subsequently developed anemia along with peripheral neuropathy and features of SACD. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin (Hb) of 9 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 fL.

What is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Explanation:

Ileal resection can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, as the terminal ileum is the primary site for absorption of the vitamin B12–intrinsic factor complex; this deficiency commonly results in macrocytic anemia, reflected by an elevated MCV of 110 fL.

  • Terminal ileum: Site of vitamin B12 absorption (B12–intrinsic factor complex).
    • Ileal resection → impaired B12 absorption → Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency:
    • Causes macrocytic (megaloblastic) anemia → MCV > 100 fL.
    • May present with neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesia, ataxia).
    • Lab findings:
      • ↓ Hemoglobin
      • ↑ MCV (e.g., 110 fL)
      • ↑ LDH, ↑ indirect bilirubin, ↓ reticulocyte count

Incorrect Options:

Iron deficiency anemia (Option A) is unlikely because it typically causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), not macrocytic anemia.

Folic acid deficiency (Option C) causes macrocytic anemia, but folate is absorbed in the jejunum, not the ileum, making it less likely after ileal resection.

Sideroblastic anemia (Option D) usually presents with microcytic or dimorphic anemia, and it's not related to ileal absorption.

questions.text: A 30 year male old patient presents to OPD with complaints of recurrent headache and nausea, MRI brain shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Meningioma

Explanation: Meningiomas are extra-axial, slow-growing tumors arising from arachnoid cap cells. On MRI (especially with contrast), they frequently show the dural tail sign - thickening and enhancement of the dura adjacent to the tumor.

  • This sign is highly suggestive of meningioma due to reactive dural vascularity and tumor infiltration.

Glioma (Option B): Intra-axial tumor without dural attachment; typically does not show dural tail sign.

Ependymoma (Option C): Usually arises from the ventricular system, particularly the 4th ventricle in children, not from dura.

Pilocytic astrocytoma (Option D): Commonly seen in children, typically in the cerebellum, and does not exhibit dural tail sign.

questions.text: Young male has sustained Femur shaft fracture after RTA and internal fixation was done. 2 days later he develops shortness of breath with confusion and petechial rash. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FES

Explanation: This patient has the classic triad of Fat Embolism Syndrome following a long bone fracture and orthopedic surgery:

  • Respiratory distress (shortness of breath)
  • Neurological symptoms (confusion, altered sensorium)
  • Petechial rash (typically on upper chest, axillae, and conjunctiva)

Fat emboli enter the circulation from bone marrow after trauma or fixation and lodge in pulmonary and systemic microvasculature, producing respiratory compromise, brain dysfunction, and a petechial rash due to dermal capillary occlusion.

ARDS (Option B): Can occur after trauma but doesn’t present with the petechial rash; onset is usually a bit later and is related to widespread inflammatory lung injury.

Pulmonary embolism (Option C): Causes acute dyspnea and hypoxia but usually lacks neurologic signs and rash; most often from DVT.

Pleural effusion (Option D): Would present with unilateral decreased breath sounds, not acute neuro changes or rash.

questions.text: What will be the effect of pulmonary embolism on V/Q graph.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - D

Explanation:

  • At point D on the V/Q graph, a pulmonary embolism causes normal ventilation but significantly decreased or absent perfusion, leading to a dramatically increased V/Q (ventilation/perfusion) Ratio that can approach infinity.
  • It is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) → Reflects the efficiency and adequacy of matching between ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.
  • Average normal V/Q ratio: About 0.8 (ventilation ≈ 4 L/min, perfusion ≈ 5 L/min).

Obstruction

Embolism
  • V/Q Ratio: Zero
  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive no ventilation, but perfusion continues. Consequently, the partial pressures of gases in the alveoli equilibrate with the venous blood, resulting in PO2 = 40 mmHg and PCO2 = 46 mmHg.
  • V/Q Ratio: Infinite
  • Partial Pressures: The alveoli receive ventilation, but no perfusion. The partial pressures of gases in the alveoli match those of the inspired air, resulting in PO2 = 149 mmHg and PCO2 = 0.3 mmHg.

 

Position

Region

V/Q  Ratio

Explanation

Upright

 

 

 

Apex

3.3 (highest)

Perfusion decreases drastically at the apex, making the V/Q ratio highest despite lower ventilation.

Middle

0.8

Both ventilation and perfusion are moderate, resulting in a balanced V/Q ratio.

Base

0.6 (lowest)

Perfusion is highest at the base, causing the V/Q ratio to be lowest despite higher ventilation.

Supine

All regions

Relatively uniform

In the supine position, gravitational effects are minimized, leading to a more uniform V/Q ratio.

questions.text: A young adult presents with facial pain and painful vesicular lesions in the mouth. Tzanck smear reveals multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1, more commonly for orofacial lesions) causes painful vesicular eruptions on the lips, gums, or oral mucosa, often preceded by a prodrome of tingling or burning.
  • On Tzanck smear (scraping from the base of a vesicle), HSV-infected keratinocytes fuse to form multinucleated giant cells.
  • The nuclei show Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions — eosinophilic bodies representing viral replication centers.

Adenovirus (Option A) typically causes respiratory tract infections and conjunctivitis but does not produce vesicular oral lesions or multinucleated giant cells .

Cytomegalovirus (Option B) infections cause “owl’s eye” intranuclear inclusions but generally do not present with vesicular lesions in the mouth .

Epstein-Barr virus (Option D) is associated with infectious mononucleosis and oral hairy leukoplakia, but not painful vesicular lesions or giant cell formation .

questions.text: Which of the following organs does this epithelium most likely belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ureter

Explanation:

The image shows Urothelium, or Transitional Epithelium, a specialized tissue found exclusively in the urinary tract—specifically, the ureter, among the given options.

  • A multilayered epithelium with four to six thick cells that can contract and expand as needed (stretchable epithelium).
  • It is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and prostatic urethra.
  • Features:
    • Cells towards the lumen are very large and called umbrella-shaped cells (typical for transitional epithelium).
    • Each cell is attached to the basement membrane by a cytoplasmic extension. The basement membrane is straight.
    • Transitional between stratified squamous and stratified columnar epithelia.
      • Cells at the surface are not squamous.
      • Deepest cells are columnar or cuboidal.
      • Middle layers are made up of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
    • Superficial cell layer (lines the lumen): Only fully differentiated layer of the epithelium → Provides an impenetrable barrier between the lumen and the bloodstream.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Gallbladder is lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli.

 Option C: Trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

Option D: Intestine is lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

questions.text: A woman comes to the clinic with breast tenderness, presence of linea nigra on her abdomen, and a bluish discoloration of the cervix. What is the most likely clinical interpretation of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Probable pregnancy

Explanation: Probable pregnancy is the most appropriate answer. The described signs - breast changes, linea nigra, and bluish discoloration of the cervix (Chadwick’s sign) - are probable signs of pregnancy. These are objective changes noted on physical examination that strongly suggest pregnancy, but are not conclusive without further confirmation (e.g., ultrasound or fetal heart sounds).

Confirmed pregnancy (Option B): Requires positive signs such as fetal heart sounds (Doppler), fetal movements felt by examiner, or ultrasound visualization of the fetus. The given findings are not confirmatory.

Normal menstrual cycle (Option C): These pigmentation and vascular changes are not seen in a normal cycle.

Menopause (Option D): Menopause is associated with amenorrhea and low estrogen signs (atrophic changes), not hyperpigmentation or cervical vascularity.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents with breathlessness, declining health, and is found to have multiple metastases. She is awake, alert, and visibly anxious. The medical team assesses that aggressive chemotherapy, radiotherapy, ICU care, and mechanical ventilation would not improve her condition and may cause harm. Despite this, the patient's daughter insists on pursuing all possible life-prolonging measures, including ICU admission. What is the most appropriate next step for the physician in managing this case?

choices.text: Convene family meeting considering patient values and goals of care
Admit to ICU and initiate aggressive treatment
Discharge and shift to home palliative care

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Discharge and shift to home palliative care

Explanation:

  • Palliative care prioritizes comfort, dignity, and quality of life when curative or aggressive measures are futile.
  • In this scenario, the patient’s advanced disease, poor prognosis, and risk of harm from invasive interventions make home-based palliative care the most ethical and beneficial approach.
  • This allows symptom control, emotional support, and dignified end-of-life care in a familiar environment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Convening a family meeting is valuable but may delay appropriate transition to comfort care and may not address immediate patient needs if clear about treatment futility.

Option B - ICU admission with aggressive treatment risks unnecessary suffering with no survival benefit.

Option D - Placebo treatment is unethical and not appropriate in end-of-life care.

questions.text: A patient on long-term hydrochlorothiazide therapy presents with features of neuropathy, heart failure, and symmetrical tingling sensations. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thiamine

Explanation:

  • Long-term diuretic use like hydrochlorothiazide can increase Thiamine excretion and cause deficiency.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency

  • Classic cause of beriberi, which can be:
    • Dry beriberi: Symmetrical peripheral neuropathy (tingling, numbness).
    • Wet beriberi: High-output heart failure and edema.
  • Long-term diuretic use like hydrochlorothiazide can increase thiamine excretion and cause deficiency. (Option B)
  • Fits neuropathy + heart failure + tingling symptoms very well.

Incorrect Options:

Selenium (Option A): Deficiency mainly causes cardiomyopathy but not neuropathy or tingling sensations.

Vitamin B12 (Option C): Causes neuropathy but usually with anemia and cognitive symptoms, not heart failure.

Zinc (Option D): Deficiency leads to skin problems and immune dysfunction, not neuropathy or heart failure.

questions.text: A 56 years old man presents with the following pathology, which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lipodermatosclerosis/eczema can occur

Explanation: The given image depicts Varicose veins, which can lead to chronic venous insufficiency, which in turn can cause complications such as venous eczema, lipodermatosclerosis, hyperpigmentation, and venous ulcers.

  • These occur due to long-standing venous hypertension causing skin and subcutaneous tissue changes.

The CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) classification for chronic venous disorders:

Feature

Classification

For clinical classification:

  • No signs of venous disease
  • Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins)
  • Varicose veins (>3 mm )
  • Edema
  • Pigmentation or eczema
  • LDS or atrophic blanche
  • Corona phlebectatica
  • Healed venous ulcer
  • Active venous ulcer
 

Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

For etiological classification:

  • Congenital
  • Primary
  • Secondary (post-thrombotic)
  • No venous cause identified

For anatomical classification:

  • Superficial veins
  • Perforator veins
  • Deep veins
  • No venous location identified

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Reflux
  • Obstruction
  • Reflux and obstruction
  • No venous pathophysiology identified

Sclerotherapy is the best treatment (Option A): Sclerotherapy is suitable for small varicosities or recurrent veins after surgery, but for primary, large saphenous varicose veins, the preferred treatment is endovenous ablation or surgical ligation/stripping, depending on the case.

Telangiectasia is rare (Option C): Telangiectasia (small dilated superficial vessels) is actually common in patients with chronic venous disease.

No possibility of venous ulcer (Option D): Venous ulcers are a well-known complication of advanced varicose veins (CEAP class 6).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent ear infections and a recent "popping" sensation in his left ear. Otoscopic examination of the left ear reveals a central perforation of the tympanic membrane.

The pure tone audiometry (PTA) results show the following:


	Right Ear: Air conduction and bone conduction thresholds are within normal limits.
	Left Ear: A significant air-bone gap is present, with bone conduction thresholds within the normal range.[1]
	These sentences were not there; PTA images were given in the exam ( I have added the closest images).


 



Based on these findings, what is the type of hearing loss is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A - Left conductive hearing loss:

Explanation:

  • Otoscopic image shows a central tympanic membrane perforation and PTA findings:

    • Left Ear: Normal bone conduction but air-bone gap → Indicates conductive hearing loss

    • Right Ear: Normal AC and BC → Normal hearing

  • A central perforation of the tympanic membrane typically leads to conductive hearing loss, as it disrupts the conduction of sound waves through the external and middle ear. Since bone conduction remains normal, the sensorineural apparatus (inner ear and beyond) is intact.

  • The air-bone gap seen in PTA clearly confirms conductive hearing loss on the left side.

Incorrect Options:

Left sensorineural hearing loss (Option B) would show elevated bone conduction thresholds, No AB gap which are not present here. The inner ear is functioning normally based on the PTA.

Right conductive hearing loss (Option C): The right ear is normal on PTA (both AC and BC), with no air-bone gap. Hence, this is incorrect.

Right sensorineural hearing loss (Option D): The right ear is completely normal in audiometric testing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with discomfort in one of his joints. Synovial fluid aspiration reveals rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pseudogout

Explanation:

  • Pseudogout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition in joints.
  • Crystals appear rhomboid-shaped and are positively birefringent under polarized light (blue when parallel, yellow when perpendicular to axis).
  • Most commonly affects large joints, especially the knee.
  • Risk factors include age, hemochromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, and joint trauma.
  • Clinically presents as acute monoarthritis resembling gout but with a different crystal morphology and birefringence pattern.
  • Seen in older adults but may occur earlier due to:
    • Hemochromatosis
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Hypothyroidism
  • Acute presentation mimics gout but is distinguished by crystal type and birefringence.

Differential Diagnosis of Acute Calcium Pyrophosphate (CPP) Crystal Arthritis (Pseudogout):

When a patient presents with acute monoarthritis, especially of a large joint like the knee, the following differentials should be considered:

  • Gout: Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid.
  • Septic Arthritis: Purulent synovial fluid with very high WBC count and positive culture.
  • Reactive Arthritis: Sterile arthritis following GI or GU infection, often with extra-articular features.
  • Seronegative Arthritis: Asymmetric oligoarthritis with negative rheumatoid factor, often in younger patients.

Gout (Option A): Caused by monosodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent under polarized light microscopy. The presentation is often at the first metatarsophalangeal joint rather than large joints.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): A chronic autoimmune polyarthritis with synovial pannus formation and positive RF or anti-CCP antibodies; joint aspiration does not reveal crystals.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): A degenerative joint disease with cartilage loss and osteophyte formation; synovial fluid is non-inflammatory and crystal-negative.

In crystal arthropathies, crystal shape and birefringence under polarized light are the key to diagnosis: Needle + negative birefringence = gout, Rhomboid + positive birefringence = pseudogout.
